answer: All Swiss mobile providers had the opportunity to register their interest in participating in SBB FreeSurf as part of the call for tenders held in spring 2020. All providers who submitted an offer were taken into account for the award. It is possible – though not currently planned – that other providers could be added at a later date.

question: Can FreeSurf damage my health?
answer: Bluetooth is one of the weakest electromagnetic sources. The technology SBB uses functions in “low energy mode”. At maximum transmission power, these devices cause about one percent of the radiation exposure of a conventional WLAN router. This means that exposure in close range (right beside the source of radiation) amounts to about 0.5% of the maximum exposure from a mobile phone. The fields can barely be measured more than 2m distance from these devices.

question: The performance of the SBB FreeSurf service is poor.
answer: All customers have access to the fastest possible connection along the route with SBB FreeSurf (as per the contract with the provider). However, this depends on the network coverage along the route and the number of people who are accessing the same antenna. The rate of data transfer is therefore better on an empty train than a fully occupied one.  However, SBB FreeSurf certainly provides better quality than WiFi on the train would.

question: Why can’t UPC customers use SBB FreeSurf?
answer: Although UPC customers make calls on the Sunrise network, they are on the UPC virtual mobile network and therefore have no access to SBB FreeSurf from Sunrise. Unfortunately, this will remain the case for the foreseeable future. An alternative is to switch (while retaining your number) to a Sunrise mobile subscription, which will give you unrestricted use of SBB FreeSurf. If you have any further questions, please contact Sunrise directly: 0800 707 707.

question: Where exactly is SBB FreeSurf offered?
answer: SBB FreeSurf is offered on all IC and IR connections within Switzerland operated by SBB, and on the SOB lines from Basel and Zurich–Lugano, as well as Bern–Burgdorf–Olten–Zurich–Chur. The RE lines Aarau–Zurich, Erstfeld–Lugano and Annemasse–St-Maurice are not included in the service. FreeSurf cannot be used on routes where regional rolling stock is sometimes used (e.g. Zurich–Chur).

question: What happens if I am on a cross-border train?
answer: The SBB FreeSurf service is not offered on cross-border Swiss trains providing long-distance services after the mobile network provider’s network has been exited. It is possible that this may occur without the mobile network provider sending a message to that effect. If the SBB FreeSurf app is nonetheless used abroad, SBB AG will not cover the costs of data traffic. In order to ensure that no charges are incurred: turn off roaming in settings under data options.

question: Can passengers from abroad also benefit from SBB FreeSurf?
answer: Passengers from abroad can browse the web for free using a SIM card from a participating provider. This is relatively easy thanks to eSIM and DUAL-SIM. There are also various offers for mobile internet in Switzerland. One of these offers is SBB FreeWiFi, available at over 80 Swiss stations.

question: Why is SBB providing free internet access in the first place?
answer: Despite the high and continually increasing number of passengers with an unlimited flat-rate contract, some customers still need free internet access on the train. In collaboration with the mobile phone providers, SBB is covering the needs of this group of customers. A good quality, stable mobile phone connection has become a basic requirement for train passengers. This also has an increasingly strong influence on passengers’ choice of transport modes. SBB is operating on the assumption that SBB FreeSurf is an interim solution. The proportion of customers with an unlimited flat-rate contract is constantly increasing, which is gradually reducing the need for free internet access.

question: Who have SBB partnered with in order to make use of free internet access?
answer: Customers of Galaxus Mobile, Quickline, Salt (Das Abo, GoMo, Lidl Connect are included), Sunrise and Swisscom can use the service.

question: I recently changed provider and cannot log in.
answer: Please check with your new provider to see if the number has been transferred yet.

question: I’ve just bought a SIM card and I’m getting an error message, why?
answer: The activation of new SIM cards has a small delay. However, you will have use of SBB FreeSurf 24 hours after purchase of the SIM card at the latest.

question: Does the free offer give the same speed of data transmission as a normal subscription?
answer: SBB FreeSurf gives customers access to the internet with the best possible speed of data transmission along train routes (depending on the availability and capacity of the mobile networks and the individual’s contract with their provider).

question: OnePlus.
answer: System Settings > Apps & notifications > Special app access > Battery optimisation > Select FreeSurf > Change to »Don't optimise».

question: A connection with SBB FreeSurf could not be established.
answer: Possible reasons:  You are not a customer of Galaxus Mobile, Quickline, Salt, Sunrise or Swisscom. The SBB FreeSurf server is currently offline.  There is no mobile service available at the moment. Bluetooth connection is not activated. The device used is no longer supported. The mobile service provider has refused to activate the connection. There is a problem with the network provider. There is an unknown problem with the system.  Tip: please try the connection again at a later time. If it still does not work, please write to us at sbb.ch/en/freesurf, so that we can analyse your situation on an individual basis.

question: I have some queries about my mobile subscription.
answer: Refer all queries about subscriptions and bills to the mobile network provider’s hotline:  Galaxus Mobile: 044 575 95 00 Quickline: 0800 841 020 Salt 0800 700 700 Sunrise: 0800 707 707 Swisscom: 0800 800 800

question: I have an unlimited mobile subscription. Does SBB FreeSurf offer me any benefit?
answer: If you have an unlimited subscription, SBB FreeSurf does not offer you any benefit (as would be the case with a WLAN connection). You will already receive the best connection quality via your mobile phone.

question: What does the registration involve?
answer: It is necessary to accept the General Terms and Conditions (GTCs) during the initial registration. SBB uses the phone number provided to check whether the mobile phone contract can be used for SBB FreeSurf. If this is the case, the customer will receive an text message with a code to complete their registration.

question: Which devices and software are supported?
answer: iOS (Apple).  All iPhones from the iPhone 6s onwards (an operating system update may be necessary). iOS 14 as a minimum must be installed. The same applies for iPads (with SIM). We recommend that you automatically update the app so that you always benefit from the latest features and improvements.   Android.  To use SBB FreeSurf on your smartphone, the Android 4.8 operating system must be installed as a minimum. The same applies to tablets (with SIM). We recommend that you automatically update the app to always benefit from all the features. Adjust this setting in the Play Store.

question: I did not receive a text message after registering.
answer: The wrong number was entered during registration. The text message registration service may be down temporarily. Registration requests will be processed when the system is restored (SMS messages will be sent later than usual).

question: Huawei.
answer: Phone settings > Battery > App launch and then set your FreeSurf to «Manage manually» and make sure everything is turned on.

question: What do I need exactly in order to use SBB FreeSurf?
answer: You need a current smartphone with an Apple (iOS) or Google (Android) operating system. The SBB FreeSurf app can be downloaded via the App Store or the Play Store.  After a one-time registration, you’ll be able to surf the web for free on SBB long-distance services.

question: How do pre-paid customers benefit from the SBB FreeSurf solution?
answer: If you have a pre-paid subscription, an amount may be deducted from the credit balance as soon as mobile services are activated in line with the conditions of the pre-paid subscription. Those registered for FreeSurf can use the app even if they have no credit on their account. There are different solutions available for Salt and Sunrise subscriptions in order to prevent the daily rate from being charged when the SBB FreeSurf is launched. Since Galaxus Mobile and Quickline do not offer pre-paid subscriptions, their customers are not affected. Salt: the customer is charged the daily rate directly. Salt checks in the background whether the SBB FreeSurf app was launched at the same time. If this is the case, the customer receives a remuneration for the daily rate in real time.   Sunrise: to stop Sunrise subscribers from being charged before using FreeSurf, the use of paid mobile data must be blocked before switching mobile data on. The customer can do this using the USSD code *170# and the call button on the keyboard. The customer enters the USSD code #170# to re-enable the use of paid mobile data outside of FreeSurf. Activation and deactivation are confirmed via a text message. Swisscom: For prepaid and postpaid customers, communication between the SBB app and the SBB server is free of charge. Customers who communicate using VPN services (company VPN, Apple Privacy Services, etc.) can only benefit from the free internet usage once they have activated the SBB FreeSurf app. Prepaid customers who are automatically charged the basic tariff can deactivate this at cockpit.swisscom.ch.

question: Samsung.
answer: Setting > Apps > top right menu > Special access > Optimise battery usage > click on «Apps not optimised» > select «All» > deactivate FreeSurf.

question: SBB FreeSurf is unavailable.
answer: The system is constantly monitored. If there is a system failure, the experts will do everything they can to make it available again as quickly as possible.

question: Xiaomi.
answer: Settings > manage apps > SBB FreeSurf > power saving mode > activate No Restrictions.

question: What exactly do I need to do to use SBB FreeSurf?
answer: You can start up the SBB FreeSurf app when you board the train. You must have Bluetooth and mobile date activated on your phone. After successfully starting the app, the user will receive confirmation by text from their mobile network provider that they can now browse the web for free. When leaving the train or terminating the connection in the SBB FreeSurf app, the user receives a notification that the free service is no longer active.

question: For which operating systems is the SBB Free Surf app available?
answer: SBB FreeSurf is available on iOS and Android.

question: Registration cannot be completed.
answer: Possible reasons:  You are not a customer of Galaxus Mobile, Quickline, Salt, Sunrise or Swisscom. The registration server is currently offline.  There is currently no data connection available. There is an unknown problem with the system.  Tip: please try the registration at a later time (this does not have to be on the train).

question: Is data protection for passengers safeguarded?
answer: Yes. SBB complies with the data protection regulations. The service has been approved by the Federal Data Protection Commissioner. SBB guarantees that they are not tracking your movements and that the location data is deleted straight away. This data is used solely to determine the duration of data use for billing. Customers expressly agree to the use of data for analysing errors before they use the free internet access (same approach as for FreeWiFi). The telecoms providers do not receive any location data for passengers on the train. Data is deleted in accordance with federal regulations.

question: Does the app help me to find my bearings at the station (station type: terminus, through-platform station, several floors etc. / facilities: stairs, lifts, escalators)?
answer: This information is currently not available. The focus of the app is the digitalisation of customer information, rather than getting around the railway station. The app in no way replaces training with navigation and mobility trainers.

question: What exactly is SBB Inclusive?
answer: With the SBB Inclusive app, people who are blind or visually impaired can receive relevant and location-based timetable information. At the station, the user is shown the next departures and can view the current departures for a given platform. Shortly after boarding an SBB long-distance train with the app open on their phone, the user will be shown which train they have boarded (train number, destination, coach number, class of travel, service zone, next stop).  The app currently works at all Swiss railway stations and on all SBB long-distance trains. Please continue to use the SBB Mobile app to plan your journeys.

question: The battery consumption of this app is higher than that of other apps. What can I do?
answer: The development team is constantly working on reducing the battery consumption of SBB Inclusive. Battery consumption depends on a range of factors, not all of which relate to the app, however. Using location tracking services, particularly GPS, increases battery usage. However, additional battery usage is kept to a minimum. When the app detects that the smartphone’s location is not changing, the app requests its location less frequently, saving battery power.

question: Why does the app only work on SBB’s long-distance trains?
answer: SBB has no influence over whether other mobility service providers install beacons in their vehicles. At present, SBB only has a secure and reliable source of data for its own facilities and services. SBB is currently testing equipping its regional fleet with the necessary technology.

question: Why is SBB Inclusive a stand-alone app?
answer: SBB Inclusive primarily addresses a specific user group and is optimised for their needs.

question: How reliable is the timetable information in the app?
answer: The timetable information in the app is the same shown on the digital displays at the station and on the train. SBB accepts no liability for the accuracy of the information provided. (Refer to the General Terms and Conditions).

question: Why is the service not available everywhere?
answer: The beacon technology required for localisation is not yet available on all trains. It requires the installation of beacons in the body of all coaches. By the end of 2023, all long-distance trains will be fitted with beacons. SBB is currently testing equipping its regional fleet with the technology. There are currently no plans for the fleets of other transport companies to be equipped with beacons.

question: How can those who are blind or visually impaired read the information?
answer: Blind and visually impaired people can use smartphones with voice output, in dark mode or with enlarged text, depending on their disability. The user interface of SBB Inclusive has been optimised for these features, so that the information is easy to access and navigate in line with the needs of the user.

question: What exactly do I need in order to use SBB Inclusive?
answer: A smartphone on which the SBB Inclusive app can be installed. In terms of operating systems, the iPhone requires iOS 14.0 or later, and Android should be 5.0 or later. To use the functions of the app, mobile data and GPS must be activated (at least when using the app), as must Bluetooth.

question: Is the app not working well/slowly at the railway station?
answer: Experience has shown that the app works faster and more reliably if you switch off the free SBB wireless internet at the station and use mobile data instead.

question: Can the app also be used by people with good vision?
answer: Yes, all information is also displayed visually and appears in the familiar SBB design.

question: Can the app be used free of charge?
answer: Yes, the app is available free of charge from the Apple AppStore and from the Google PlayStore.

question: Why do I only receive the train information once I am on the train?
answer: Due to the range of the beacons (the train acts like a Faraday cage) the app only starts searching for the train once the user enters the coach. Experience has shown that the app works faster and more reliably if you switch off the free SBB wireless internet at the station. For the app to work, you must be connected to the internet.

question: What languages is SBB Inclusive available in?
answer: German, French, Italian, and English.

question: When boarding the train, the app does not work, or only does so slowly.
answer: Experience has shown that the app works faster and more reliably if you switch off the free SBB wireless internet at the station and use mobile data instead. You should also make sure that your Bluetooth is activated.

question: Sitting on the train, I go to the “At the station” tab. Sometimes it shows me a previous station. What do I have to do to update the station?
answer: The GPS information is provided by the device. If the localisation data does not update itself, there is nothing we can do in terms of the app. Since the train also functions like a Faraday cage, finding your location when on the train is harder than when you are at the station. You can find out what GPS data your device is currently using by opening a map application (e.g. Google Maps) and allowing it to locate you.

question: How can I give feedback?
answer: Direct in the app via the contact form. Or alternatively, use the feedback form at the bottom of this page.

question: How does SBB Inclusive know where I am?
answer: Two different technologies are used to locate the user and provide them with relevant information:   At the station, GPS signals are used. If the user is at a railway station, the timetable information relevant to that station will be provided.  For coach-specific localisation whilst on board the train, the app uses beacon technology, which works via Bluetooth signals. All data is processed only in the background and SBB neither stores it nor uses it for other purposes.

question: What accessibility features does the app support?
answer: Voice over, dark mode, font magnification and transcription of audio announcements at the station.

question: Is data protection guaranteed?
answer: You can find information on how we handle your data here:                                             Go to the SBB Inclusive Privacy Policy

question: How do I reserve seats for a group of 10 or more people?
answer: There are special rules for groups of 10 or more people.                                              Go to information and seat reservations for groups of 10 or more people

question: For reservations for more than one person, are all the seats always next to each other?
answer: Yes. However, if there are not enough seats next to each other available, you will get a message asking you to split up the reservation. Even if the seat numbers are not always consecutive, the seats will still be in the same compartment.

question: I already have a Eurail Pass. Where can I make a seat reservation?
answer: Online: at eurail.comLink opens in new window.. By telephone: via the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). In person: at any public transport point of sale.

question: Which trains within Switzerland can I reserve seats for?
answer: Trains for which you can reserve seats are marked with an R (meaning a reservation is possible) or an R in a rectangular frame (meaning a reservation is compulsory) in the timetable.  For seat reservation for touristic trains such as the Gotthard Panorama Express, the Bernina Express or the Glacier Express etc. please contact a public transport point of sale.

question: How much does it cost to reserve a seat?
answer: The reservation fee for seats is CHF 5 per person. For connections involving changes, the reservation on the connecting train is free of charge. For trains subject to a surcharge (e.g. the Glacier Express), the reservation fee is included in the surcharge.

question: Can I exchange a seat reservation for a journey to Europe that I booked online for one at another time / on another date?
answer: In some cases it is possible to exchange your seat reservation before the departure of the train and in accordance with the conditions that you were informed of during booking. Not all products and services can be exchanged. Please refer to the supplementary travel details you received when you made your online purchase on SBB.ch. If you have any questions, please contact the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.) or go to a public transport point of sale.

question: I already have an Interrail Pass. Where can I make a seat reservation?
answer: Online: at interrail.euLink opens in new window.. By telephone: via the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). In person: at any public transport point of sale.

question: Can seat reservations be refunded?
answer: Generally no. Seat reservations cannot be refunded or exchanged. Special conditions apply to trains subject to a surcharge. There is an exception if the rolling stock used for the train changes at short notice and your reservations are made invalid. Ask the train crew to provide you with written confirmation. You can obtain a refund of the CHF 5 at the ticket counter or you can exchange it for a promotional code online (to be used for any service when making your next online or mobile booking).

question: Which trains to Europe require a seat reservation?
answer: When reserving seats for train journeys to Europe, different prices and provisions apply according to the country.                                             Go to the country overview for seat reservations

question: Can I reserve seats in the family coach?
answer: Yes. Please visit a staffed public transport point of sale or contact the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.).

question: Where can I find the current SBB Restaurant menu?
answer: You can find the SBB Restaurant menu offer here:                                             Go to the SBB Restaurant offer

question: How can I reserve a seat in the dining car of an international railway?
answer: Different international railways have varying conditions for reserving a seat in the dining car.                                             Go to the service offer for international dining cars

question: How can I reserve a seat in an SBB Restaurant?
answer: Go to the seat reservation in the SBB Restaurant

question: Do I have to respect a lead time when making a reservation?
answer: You can reserve seats up to one day before departure. You can receive your reservation confirmation either at the ticket counter or by post.  If you would like to have the reservation sent to you by post, please allow three working days for delivery.

question: My bike is less than two meters long and still doesn’t fit in the rack on the train. What can I do?
answer: In older coaches, the bicycle mounts are sometimes not set up for modern mountain bikes with 29-inch wheels and wider tires. Due to the limited space available, it is unfortunately not possible to optimise these bicycle spaces. Therefore, try turning the handlebars, removing a wheel, or maybe even let some air out of the tyre or use a bike lock to attach your bicycle to the hook. If none of this helps, contact the on-board staff so that an alternative location on the train can be found if necessary.

question: Where and how can I buy tickets for my bicycle?
answer: Purchase bike tickets. You can purchase bike tickets online on SBB.ch, via the SBB Mobile app, from ticket machines or at a public transport point of sale. Before you buy a ticket. Have you checked the timetable to see whether a bicycle reservation is necessary for the route you want to take? If a reservation is required, we recommend that you make the reservation first and only then buy the bike ticket. Unfortunately, it is not currently possible to purchase the reservation together with the ticket.                                             Go to bike space reservations.                                                                 Purchase for yourself and for your bike in the SBB Mobile app. If you would like to buy the ticket for your bike together with your own ticket, proceed as follows:  Enter the route and select your desired connection. Select ‘Tickets from CHF...’. Tap on ‘Edit passenger’ (pencil symbol). Tap the plus sign at the bottom next to the bicycle symbol once. Tap on ‘Accept’. The bike ticket will now appear together with your ticket in the overview and you can buy the tickets together. Would you like to buy a ticket and a bike ticket for several people at the same time? Add a bicycle for each co-passenger. Only one bike can be taken per person. Children aged under 16 who are accompanied by an adult do not need a bike ticket.   Purchase in the SBB Mobile app (if you already have a ticket for yourself).  Enter the route and select your desired connection.  Select ‘Tickets from CHF...’. Tap on ‘Edit passenger’ (pencil symbol). (Only if you do NOT have a GA Travelcard: enter a new fictitious co-passenger with your own name. To do this, please swap your first name and last name around and enter a GA Travelcard as the travelcard). Tap the plus sign at the bottom next to the bicycle symbol once (or several times if you want to buy several bike tickets). Tap on ‘Accept’. The bicycle ticket will now appear in the overview and you can buy the ticket.  Online on SBB.ch with a login.  Here’s how it works:  Enter the route into the timetable and select your preferred connection. When entering the passengers, click on ‘Process passengers | reductions’. Enter the number of bike tickets you would like in the field following the ‘Discount cards’ field. If you do not need a ticket for yourself, check the box next to the text ‘Passenger already has a valid ticket or other valid travel document’. Click on ‘Accept’. Choose between ‘single journey’ and ‘single and return journey’. Go to the check-out and purchase the ticket with your preferred payment method.  Online on SBB.ch without a login. Here’s how it works:  Enter the route into the timetable and select your preferred connection. When entering passengers, click on ‘Add passenger’ and add the name of the passenger/co-passenger. At the same time, enter the number of bike tickets you would like in the field following the ‘Discount cards’ field. Enter the number of dog tickets you would like in the field following the ‘Discount cards’ field. If you do not need a ticket for yourself, check the box next to the text ‘Passenger already has a valid ticket or other valid travel document’. Click on ‘Accept’. Choose between ‘single journey’ and ‘single and return journey’. Go to the check-out and purchase the ticket with your chosen payment method.  Where and how can I buy a Bike Day Pass? You can purchase Bike Day Passes online on SBB.ch, via the SBB Mobile app, from ticket machines or at a public transport point of sale. The Bike Day Pass is automatically offered during purchase on SBB.ch or via SBB Mobile (see the question ‘How can I buy tickets for my bicycle?’) as soon as the price for the bike ticket reaches the amount of CHF 15. Alternatively, you can buy the Bike Day Pass directly online at SBB.ch or via the SBB Mobile app in the ‘Shop & Services’ tab.                                             Purchase the Bike Day Pass online.                                                                Please note that the area of validity for the Bike Day Pass differs from that of normal Point-to-Point Tickets and GA/Half Fare Travelcards.                                             Go to the validity of bike tickets (“yes” in column T600 for bikes)                         Link opens in new window.                                       Where and how do I buy an annual bike pass? The annual bike pass is available for CHF 260 per bike per year on the SwissPass. If you already hold a SwissPass, you can purchase an annual bike pass online or at any staffed point of sale. The annual bike pass is integrated onto your SwissPass.  Buy an annual bike pass with SwissPass online  If you do not hold a SwissPass  Please note that the area of validity for the annual bike pass differs from that of normal Point-to-Point Tickets and GA/Half Fare Travelcards.                                             Go to the validity of bike tickets (“yes” in column T600 for bikes)                         Link opens in new window.

question: Can I cancel my annual bike pass and have it refunded?
answer: If you have used the annual bike pass for no more than one month and would like to cancel it, you will receive 50% of the purchase price as a refund. If you have used the annual bike pass for two months, you can still get 25% of the purchase price back. Cancellation is not possible if you have used it for more than two months.

question: When do I need a bike space reservation and for which trains?
answer: From 21 March to 31 October, you will need a bike space reservation for your bike on InterCity (IC) trains. In the timetable, trains requiring reservation are marked with the bike reservation symbol.  Every day for the IC2/21 lines through the Gotthard Base Tunnel (Basel/Zurich–Ticino). Every day for the IC5/51 lines at the southern foot of the Jura (Basel–Biel/Bienne, Rorschach/Zurich–Biel/Bienne–Lausanne/Geneva). From Friday to Sunday as well as Easter Monday, Ascension Day, Whit Monday and 1 August for all other InterCity lines.   You will also need a reservation throughout the year for the Swiss section of the route for the following trains operating internationally: EuroCity (EC), Intercity-Express (ICE), Railjet (RJX) and InterCity (IC) (Zurich–Schaffhausen). Please make sure to check whether your chosen train is subject to reservation in good time so that you can take your bike along with you. The online and mobile timetables are updated daily. Please note that you cannot cancel or rebook reservations for bicycle spaces.

question: Do I need tickets for children’s bicycles?
answer: For children under 6 years old, children’s bikes are considered hand luggage and can be transported free of charge. Bambini e ragazzi in possesso di un AG Ragazzi o di un AG Famiglia Ragazzi possono portare gratuitamente la bici anche senza accompagnamento. Children with a GA Travelcard for Children or a GA Travelcard Familia for Children can take their bike with them for free even when on their own. If these conditions are not met, you will need a ticket for each children’s bike. For bicycles belonging to children aged 6 and over, you must buy a bike space reservation for trains where reservations for bicycles are compulsory.                                             Go to “Do I have to make a reservation for children’s bicycles?”

question: For which trains to Ticino can I reserve a bicycle storage space and how can I do so?
answer: The IC trains on lines 2/21 (Basel/Zurich–Ticino) need to be reserved every day of the week during the cycling season from 21 March to 31 October. You can reserve bicycle spaces using the SBB Mobile app. Bicycle spaces on EuroCity trains to/from Italy can also be reserved for journeys within Switzerland. You can reserve bicycle spaces using the SBB Mobile app.

question: How can I see which coaches have the bike spaces?
answer: The coach and space number is indicated on your reservation confirmation. On the day of your journey, you can check the train formation to see in which sector the coach with your reserved space is located. The train formation can be found in the SBB Mobile app and on the online timetable at SBB.ch. In the app, swipe the desired connection from right to left to do this. For the desired connection, click on the ‘Show details’ button in the online timetable. Then click on the arrow in the bottom left until the route and train formation are shown. Via SBB Mobile: Image legend: Choose a connection in the SBB Mobile app. Then swipe the connection from right to left. Image legend: The train formation will be displayed after you swipe.  In the timetable on SBB.ch: Image legend: Choose your preferred connection in the SBB.ch timetable. Click on the button labelled «Show details» in the connection details. Image legend: By clicking on the arrow in the bottom left (Trip info), you can change the view and show the train formation. At the railway station. At many stations, the coach numbers can be seen on the blue displays on the platform. These may also display the bicycle pictograms.

question: What ticket do I need for a tandem?
answer: For tandems or special bicycles in general (all types of bicycles which do not fit into the normal bicycle racks or are longer than two metres, e.g. cargo bicycles, recumbent bicycles) you need a Point-to-Point Bike Ticket, a Bike Day Pass ticket or an annual bike pass. Please note the provisions of the transport companies regarding whether and under what conditions the transport of special bicycles is permitted.                                             Go to “Which bikes can I load myself?”

question: Do I have to make a reservation for children’s bicycles?
answer: No reservation is necessary for bicycles, balance bikes and scooters belonging to children below 6 years old. A reservation is required for bicycles belonging to children between the ages of 6 and 16.                                               For more information, see the question: “Do I need tickets for children’s bicycles?”

question: Which bikes and vehicles cannot be transported on public transport?
answer: Vehicles with combustion engines (e.g. mopeds), triple tandem bikes, multi-seater horizontal bicycles, personal transporter (e.g. Segways) and electric mopeds.

question: Which bikes can I load myself?
answer: We distinguish between ordinary bicycles and special bicycles. Ordinary bicycles. The total length of ordinary bicycles must not exceed two metres. For self-service loading of bicycles, it does not matter whether the bicycle is electrically assisted or not.  Mountain bikes. Racing bikes. Gravel bikes. Everyday bikes etc.  Special bicycles. All bicycles which are longer than two meters, usually tandems, recumbent bicycles and cargo bicycles. Bikes allowed on InterCity (IC), InterRegio (IR), EuroCity (EC), InterCityExpress (ICE) and Railjet (RJX) trains within Switzerland.  Ordinary bicycles that are no more than two meters long. Bikes allowed on RegioExpress (RE), S-Bahn (S) and Regio (R) train categories.   In these train categories you can transport ordinary bicycles and special bicycles. Particularly in the case of special bikes, please note that escape routes, entrances and exits must always be kept clear. If you are taking special bikes along with you, you are advised to avoid peak travel times.                                              More about bikes that are allowed

question: Is it possible to reserve bicycle spaces on trains which do not require reservation?
answer: No, bicycle space reservations can only be made on trains where reservations are compulsory (bicycle symbol with R ). On all other trains, it is not possible to reserve bicycle spaces.

question: Do I need to pay for my bike?
answer: Yes. You also need a separate ticket for your bike for self-service loading of bicycles.

question: Can I take my e-moped on the train?
answer: No. You are not allowed to transport e-mopeds on the train. By e-mopeds, we mean any motorcycle-like vehicle which runs on electricity alone, regardless of its power.

question: How do I buy a bike space reservation?
answer: If a bike space reservation is mandatory on your desired connection, it is best to purchase one with the SBB Mobile app. You can identify mandatory bicycle reservations by the bicycle symbol with R . With the SBB Mobile app.  Open the app. Enter the route and select your desired connection. Tap on ‘Tickets from CHF...’. Tap on ‘Edit passenger’ (pencil symbol). Tap the plus sign at the bottom next to the bicycle symbol once. Tap on ‘Accept’. Scroll down to ‘Additional offers’ then select ‘Seat reservation only’. Click on ‘Purchase ticket for CHF 2.00’.  Would you like to reserve bicycle spaces for other co-passengers? Tap the plus sign next to the bike symbol several times until you reach the desired number of bike reservations. Then complete the reservation as described above. On SBB.ch. The purchase of bike space reservations on SBB.ch is set to be introduced in April 2024. At the station.  All bike space reservations are also available at staffed public transport points of sale. Via the SBB Contact Center. Alternatively, you can reserve your bicycle space via the SBB Contact Centre on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.) no later than 3 working days before the start of your journey.

question: Can I choose the storage space when making a reservation?
answer: The reservation system allocates spaces automatically. Unfortunately, it is not possible to select a specific coach.

question: What does transport or carriage of bikes mean?
answer: Self-service loading of bicycles means taking one bicycle or e-bike per person with you on the train. You can do this on most SBB trains and most trains of other transport companies, as well as with some bus companies (e.g. PostBuses). You place or hang the bicycle or e-bike in the designated area in the vehicle yourself.                                             All information about self-service loading of bicycles

question: Can I take my bike with me as hand luggage?
answer: Yes, you can in certain cases.                                             Go to bicycles as hand luggage

question: Can I change or cancel my bicycle reservation?
answer: No. Unfortunately, this is not possible at the moment.

question: On which trains can I reserve bicycle spaces using the SBB Mobile app?
answer: You can reserve bike spaces via the SBB Mobile app on all trains within Switzerland if reservation is mandatory at the time of your journey.

question: Can I transport a bicycle trailer on the train?
answer: Yes. Please note that boarding doors and the doors between coaches on some SBB trains are only suitable for trailer widths of a maximum of 80cm and 70cm respectively. Your bicycle trailer counts as hand luggage and therefore does not require a ticket.

question: What general rules apply to the self-service loading of bicycles on trains?
answer: When taking a bike on public transport, it is a requirement that you are able to load and unload it independently and store it in the holder provided. Furthermore, only one bike can be taken per person. Self-service loading of bicycles is only possible if there is sufficient space in the vehicles and it does not hinder other passengers. On modes of transport which require reservation, bicycle transport is only guaranteed if you have bought a bike space reservation in advance (check the online timetable). Escape routes, entrances and exits and access points to the engine driver’s cabin must always be kept clear. Bicycles that are very dirty may be excluded from carriage.

question: Is the annual bike pass non-transferable?
answer: Yes, the annual bike pass is integrated onto a personal SwissPass and is therefore only valid for that person.

question: How can I transport my folding bicycle on the train?
answer: Folding bicycles should be stowed as luggage items under the seat, in the luggage stowage/niches or in other suitable places where they do not hinder other passengers or occupy any bicycle spaces.  You do not need a reservation or a ticket for this.  No packing/bag is required.

question: How many bicycle spaces can I reserve at the same time?
answer: If there are enough available spaces in a coach, you can reserve up to 9 bicycle spaces at the same time. However, it is not possible to reserve more spaces at the same time than are available in a given individual coach.

question: I have an annual bike pass. Do I also need a reservation?
answer: Yes, even with an annual bike pass, you still need a reservation for trains where reservations are required.

question: How much does it cost to reserve a bicycle space?
answer: A bike space reservation costs CHF 2 for all trains within Switzerland that require a reservation. For connections involving changes, the reservation on the connecting train is free of charge.

question: I will be travelling in 1st class. Can I also reserve a space for my bicycle in a 1st class coach?
answer: The reservation system allocates spaces automatically. Unfortunately, it is not possible to choose between 1st and 2nd class when making the reservation.

question: Do I need a reservation for my scooter?
answer: You do not need a reservation for your (e-)scooter, even on trains which require reservations. Exception: your (e-)scooter is too big to be stowed in a luggage stowage/niche or under or between the seats.

question: I would like to reserve spaces for three bicycles but a message saying ‘fully booked’ has appeared. Why is this?
answer: Either the train is already fully booked, or the coach does not have three bicycle spaces available in the same coach. Try to split up your reservation (e.g. two bicycles and one bicycle) or choose another connection.

question: I have made a reservation for my bicycle, but I have only received a coach number, and no bike space number. Why is this?
answer: If your reservation only provides a coach number, you can store your bicycle in the train’s luggage compartment. SBB staff will assist you with loading and unloading.

question: Can my (e-)scooter come with me on the train?
answer: Yes. You can take both e-scooters and normal scooters on the train.   Please stow your (electric) scooter in a suitable location on the train and ensure that it does not protrude into the passageway or take up bicycle spaces (e.g. under or between the seats). If your (electric) scooter can be folded, we kindly request that you place it folded up under the seat or in the luggage racks/niches. This ensures that more space is available for luggage, prams etc. Both foldable and unfoldable (electric) scooters are transported free of charge, provided the largest wheel has a diameter of no more than 30cm or less than 12 inches).

question: Is it possible to rebook or cancel reservations which have already been made using the SBB Mobile app?
answer: No. Unfortunately, this is not possible at the moment.

question: Can groups of 10 or more people load their bicycles themselves?
answer: No, we cannot offer self-service loading of bicycles for groups of 10 or more people.                                             More about self-service loading of bicycles for groups

question: Can e-bikes be taken on trains to Europe using self-service loading?
answer: E-bikes with pedal assist up to 25km/h can generally be transported like normal bikes on all international railways. There are a few key points to note:  S-Pedelecs (e-bikes with a number plate) cannot be transported on journeys to Germany or Austria. In some countries, the battery cannot be charged during the journey and must be attached to the bike during rail transport. The transport of a spare battery is not permitted in many countries.  Before setting off on an e-bike trip abroad, it’s advisable to find out about the rules of the road in the country you are visiting as they can sometimes differ from those applicable in Switzerland.

question: What do I have to be aware of when planning a trip to Europe with my bike?
answer: SBB and the railways in the neighbouring countries provide international self-service loading of bicycles. In addition to a valid ticket for yourself and your bicycle, in most cases, you also need a bike space reservation for your journey. Bike tickets and reservations for international journeys with a bicycle can currently only be purchased from the rail company of the neighbouring country concerned. Go to «Where can I find more country-specific information about bicycle transport by rail?»  It’s also important to note:  Availability of bike transport on trains to Europe is limited or, in some cases, not available. A bike space reservation is generally required on international services. Please note that S-Pedelecs (e-bikes with a number plate) cannot be transported on journeys to Germany or Austria.                                              More on self-service loading of bikes on trains to Europe

question: Where can I find more country-specific information about bicycle transport by rail?
answer: The following links provide you with information from the rail operators on travelling with a bike in the respective countries:  Germany DBLink opens in new window.  Austria ÖBBLink opens in new window. Italy TrenitaliaLink opens in new window. France SNCFLink opens in new window. Belgium SNCBLink opens in new window. Croatia HZPPLink opens in new window. Denmark DSBLink opens in new window. Hungary MAVLink opens in new window. Luxembourg CFLLink opens in new window. The Netherlands NSLink opens in new window. Norway VyLink opens in new window. Poland PKP IntercityLink opens in new window. Czech Republic CDLink opens in new window. Serbia Srbija VozLink opens in new window. Slovakia ZSSKLink opens in new window. Slovenia SZLink opens in new window. Spain RenfeLink opens in new window. Sweden SJLink opens in new window.

question: Where can I buy the ticket and the reservation for an international journey with a bike?
answer: Tickets and reservations for international journeys with a bicycle can be purchased directly online from the rail company of the neighbouring country:  Germany: bahn.deLink opens in new window. Austria: oebb.atLink opens in new window. Italy: trenitalia.itLink opens in new window. France: sncf-connect.comLink opens in new window.  At the moment, you cannot buy tickets or reservations for international journeys with a bike from SBB.

question: Can I take my bike for free as hand luggage on all trains to Europe?
answer: SBB cannot guarantee that bikes in bags can also be transported on foreign trains. On night trains for example, bikes in bags cannot be carried unless information to the contrary is provided. Bikes may also not be stowed in spaces where they inconvenience other passengers and/or train crew. Bikes must not block passageways. Please note the special maximum dimensions for bike transport covers for the following countries (not a complete list):  TGV Lyria: max. length 130cm, max. width 90cm.  Italy: max. length 110cm, max. width 80cm, max. height 45cm.

question: How can I see if an international service carries bikes at all when checking the timetable?
answer: You can check the route you wish to travel. You can find international connections that permit you to take your bike on the train (excluding Italy) by visiting the route planer (hafas.bene-system.com) and selecting the number of bicycles from the drop-down menu ‘carriage of Bicycles required’.                                             Go to the route planner                         Link opens in new window.                                       In France, bicycles and trailers can be transported free of charge on regional trains, provided there is enough space. Tandem bicycles can only be transported in trains with luggage vans.                                             More information on taking your bike with you in France                         Link opens in new window.                                       Specific country and night train information is also available:  By telephone: from the SBB Contact Center 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). In person: from all public transport points of sale.

question: Where can I obtain information on construction?
answer: Please refer to the online timetable for information on construction. Rail replacement buses usually have a low-floor entrance. If a special solution is required for travellers in wheelchairs, this will also be indicated in the timetable. If you have any questions, please contact the Contact Center Handicap at least two hours in advance. Certain construction sites contain obstacles that a blind or visually impaired person cannot navigate alone. In these case, assistance can be organised with the Contact Center Handicap.

question: What are the maximum dimensions for a wheelchair on public transport?
answer: Width overall 70 cm, length 125 cm, height 137 cm The Mobilifts are designed to carry a load of 320kg  As a rule, no assistance can be provided for boarding and alighting with wheelchairs that are larger and/or heavier than normal. The list of permitted drivable aids is given on the page ‘Travel planning’.                                             Travel planning

question: I have booked assistance. Can I receive confirmation?
answer: If you provide the Contact Center Handicap with your e-mail address, you will receive a travel confirmation with the itinerary and further information about your journey. You will also find out which staff will assist you with boarding and alighting  If you have provided a mobile phone number, you will receive a text message 30 minutes before your reserved boarding/alighting assistance with information on which group of people (transport crew, passenger attendants, SOS Bahnhofhilfe assistants, customer assistants or shuttle drivers) will be assisting you.

question: At which stations can I reserve assistance?
answer: You can request assistance with boarding and alighting any non-accessible public transport connection. You can see whether the connection you’ve selected is accessible in the online timetable on SBB.ch. Reserve the assistance you need here:   in the Assisted Mobility Notification and Information System (AMO) on swisspass.ch/handicap. with the Contact Center Handicap by dialling the toll-free number 0800 007 102 (+41 800 007 102 from abroad).

question: What does the Contact Center Handicap do?
answer: Go to Contact Center Handicap services

question: I've had surgery and I need help to get home from the hospital. My difficulties with travelling are only temporary in nature. Can I call on the help of the Contact Center Handicap?
answer: Yes, you can call on our help even if you only have temporary difficulties with travelling. However, this is only for boarding and alighting. If you require accompaniment during the train journey, please contact COMPAGNA. This service is subject to payment.  Compagna Reisebegleitung Eschenstrasse 1 9000 St. Gallen Tel. +41 71 220 1607 info@compagna-reisebegleitung.chLink opens in new window. compagna-reisebegleitung.chLink opens in new window.                                             COMPAGNA                         Link opens in new window.

question: How far in advance do I need to book a shuttle service?
answer: We recommend that you make your request with the Contact Center Handicap as early as possible. However, the absolute minimum prior warning is two hours before departure.

question: Can I take an companion on the shuttle with me?
answer: Yes, the Companion Travelcard is also valid for the shuttle.

question: Can the shuttle drivers help with boarding and alighting?
answer: Yes, the drivers will help you transfer from the train or bus to the shuttle and vice versa. You can obtain information about this from the Contact Center Handicap. At some stations, the shuttle staff can offer boarding and alighting assistance with a folding ramp directly at the station.

question: Which trains have low-floor coaches?
answer: The online timetable provides information about the accessibility of every connection.                                              More information about the online timetable can be found on the ‘Travel planning’ page

question: Is the information about accessibility reliable on the online timetable?
answer: Yes, the information is updated in real time. However, very short-notice changes can occur. Discrepancies are possible in the case of system issues and disruptions.

question: One person in our group is travelling in a wheelchair. Can this person travel in our group?
answer: If a wheelchair user will be travelling with you on a group trip, please let us know when you book the group trip. If possible, we will place your group in or near the passenger coach with a wheelchair compartment. At the same time, please inform the Contact Center Handicap of any assistance which may be required during boarding and alighting. If several people are travelling in wheelchairs, a maximum of 10 people in wheelchairs can travel together on double-deck trains (IC2000/IC2020). On board all other trains, groups may only be able to travel in different compartments or split between several trains, depending on the size of the group. You can obtain further information from the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0 08/min.).

question: Is the transport crew always informed about travellers with disabilities?
answer: Yes. If you have registered with the Contact Center Handicap, the transport crew will receive a message about passengers travelling with disabilities.

question: Which companies are responsible for the shuttle service?
answer: SBB has concluded contracts with various local providers of transport for passengers with disabilities. All providers were checked for quality and flexibility.

question: How long does the shuttle wait for a delayed train or in the event of a train cancellation?
answer: The waiting time is up to 30 minutes.

question: Accessibility information in the online timetable is incorrectI was on the platform and the train that arrived did not have any low-floor coaches, so I could not get on board Where has this incorrect information come from?
answer: Information about low-floor trains cannot be guaranteed to be correct. If there is a breakdown, a replacement vehicle will have to be used which might not have a low floor. The online timetable is updated in real time. However, changes to rolling stock are always possible at short notice.

question: What is the Companion Card?
answer: The  Companion Travelcard gives travellers with disabilities (wheelchair users, people with mobility problems, blind people, people with visual impairments and people with intellectual disabilities) the opportunity to take a companion and/or a guide dog/assistance dog with them at no extra cost.

question: Is the Companion Travelcard valid for the shuttle service?
answer: Yes.

question: How many wheelchairs can be transported in one shuttle?
answer: A maximum of two wheelchairs and one accompanying person can be transported. Make sure to mention the number of passengers when registering. For group travel with more than two wheelchair users, we recommend that you plan and book your journey well in advance.

question: Where is the meeting point to get assistance?
answer: If you would like assistance for boarding with a wheelchair: the meeting point is by the Mobilift (yellow lifting platform) or the folding ramp that generally is located in the middle of the platform. We will be there waiting for your 10 minutes before your scheduled assistance.  You can find all the information on meeting points for other forms of assistance for boarding and alighting on the ‘Accessible travel’ page.                                             Go to the information on meeting points

question: How do I proceed with my luggage?
answer: Customer assistants will not carry any luggage. If you are able to carry your own luggage, the Contact Center Handicap can guarantee that you will be provided with assistance in boarding and alighting. However, if you are travelling with a lot of luggage, it is best to drop it off. Use luggage registration at a staffed railway station for this. Usually, your luggage is ready for collection two days later. More information at sbb.ch/en/luggage or from the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.).

question: Can the shuttle service take me home?
answer: No, the shuttle service can only take you to the nearest accessible public transport stop. The requirements of the temporary shuttle service measure were laid out by the Federal Office of Transport (FOT).

question: Do I also have to pay a night supplement with the Companion Travelcard?
answer: No. The passenger travelling free of charge with the Companion Travelcard does not have to pay the night supplement.

question: How do I book assistance on the Glacier Express (MGBahn)?
answer: In order to reserve assistance on the Glacier Express, Contact Center Handicap will need to know your date of travel, the train’s departure and arrival times and the number of your reserved seat. Your ticket and seat reservation for the Glacier Express can be obtained:  by telephone from the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.) directly from the MGBahn reservation office on 0041 (0)848 642 442 or  by e-mail to: railcenter@mgbahn.chLink opens in new window..  With this information, all you need to do is call 0800 007 102 24 hours before the train departs to reserve boarding and alighting assistance.

question: How do I book assistance on the Bernina Express (RhB)?
answer: To reserve assistance on the Bernina Express, SBB Contact Center Handicap will need to know your date of travel, the train’s departure and arrival times and the number of your reserved seat.  Your ticket and seat reservation for the Bernina Express can be obtained:  by telephone from the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.) directly from the Rhaetian Railway on 0041 (0)81 288 65 65 or  by e-mail to: railservice@rhb.chLink opens in new window..  With this information, all you need to do is call 0800 007 102 24 hours before the train departs to reserve boarding and alighting assistance.

question: How does the shuttle service work?
answer: Please contact the Contact Center Handicap at least two hours before you will require assistance.   The Contact Center Handicap informs you of the route the shuttle service will take and organises the transport.  The shuttle service brings you to the next accessible stop. The shuttle journey is included in the ticket price.

question: Is the shuttle service intended for all types of disabilities?
answer: A shuttle service is available for wheelchair users and people with walking disabilities.  Blind and visually impaired people are generally able to navigate stairs and steps and thus do not require a shuttle service.

question: Who is responsible for the timetable data?
answer: The data is provided by the individual transport companies and infrastructure operators.

question: What are the maximum dimensions and weights for wheelchairs?
answer: Width 70cm. Length 125cm. Height 137cm. Weight 320kg (maximum load for the Mobilift).  As a rule, no assistance can be provided with boarding and alighting with wheelchairs that are larger and/or heavier than these limits.                                             More information on travelling with a wheelchair or rollator

question: What discounts can I get on international services?
answer: You can find detailed information on discounts for journeys from Switzerland to another country under ‘International travel’ on the ‘Travel discounts for passengers with a disability’ page.                                              Go to information for international travel

question: I'm going to be visiting Switzerland as a tourist, and I'm a wheelchair user. I've got identification documents for disabled travel that were not issued in Switzerland. Will I benefit from travel discounts in Switzerland?
answer: No, with foreign ID documents there is no discount when purchasing tickets in Switzerland for travellers with disabilities. Please make enquiries in your country of residence about discounts and purchase your tickets for your journey in Switzerland there.

question: Can I board the train with my Segway?
answer: No. Use of Segways, quad bikes and vehicles with a combustion engine is prohibited both at railway stations and on trains. You can find information about transporting assistance equipment on trains under ‘Travel planning’.                                               Travel planning

question: With which transport companies is it possible to travel independently?
answer: Obtain information on the accessibility of public transport connections and the equipment available on individual vehicles in the online timetable on SBB.ch or through the Contact Center Handicap by dialling 0800 007 102 (toll-free from within Switzerland). You can reach the Contact Center Handicap from abroad by dialling +41 800 007 102.

question: Can I buy my tickets from the Contact Center Handicap?
answer: No, the Contact Center Handicap does not sell tickets. Tickets can be purchased:  from the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.) (Tickets for Switzerland, international travel, reservations for seats and wheelchair spaces). online at SBB.ch (tickets for Switzerland and tickets for Europe). on the SBB Mobile app (tickets for Switzerland only, seat reservations). at SBB ticket counters (entire range). at SBB ticket machines (tickets for Switzerland).

question: I want to order a GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons. Will I receive the GA Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: Yes. The GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons is only available on the SwissPass (as a red card and on your smartphone).

question: Where can I find general information about the GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons on the SwissPass?
answer: More information about the GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons on the SwissPass can be found on the page GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons.                                              For Disabled Persons

question: Is the SBB.ch website accessible?
answer: SBB is continuously optimising many of its services on websites, apps and in PDF documents to make them fully accessible, ensuring that we make good use of assistive technology. For instance, blind and visually impaired customers can read PDF documents on sbb.ch/handicap using a screen reader. In March 2019, the ‘Access for All’ foundation certified the accessibility of SBB.ch. An independent team of accessibility specialists tested whether the website was accessible and whether the standards for certification were met.

question: My girlfriend uses a wheelchair and I want to travel with her on the IC 2000 to Zurich. I have a 2nd class GA Travelcard. Am I allowed to travel with her in 1st class?
answer: Yes. On InterCity tilting trains (ICNs) and on double-deck trains (IC 2000), the wheelchair compartment and a toilet accessible for wheelchair users are located in 1st class. If you are travelling as an accompanying person and your girlfriend has a Companion Card (Disabled Passenger’s ID Card), then you are also allowed to travel in 1st class.

question: What is changing for customers thanks to the Disability Discrimination Act (DDA)?
answer: The Disability Discrimination Act(DDA) stipulates that public transport must be accessible and, as such, generally available for autonomous use by passengers with disabilities by the beginning of 2024. As autonomous boarding and alighting must be possible for every connection, folding ramp and Mobilift assistance will be made available during off-peak times and at additional stations and stops from 2024. If a stop or boarding area does not have step-free access or if staff assistance is not available, passengers are offered a shuttle service (transport in accessible vehicles on the road) as a temporary measure. You can reserve the shuttle service by calling the Contact Center Handicap.

question: My electric scooter exceeds the permitted maximum weight for assistance with boarding and alighting. Am I allowed to travel nevertheless?
answer: If you use an aid that exceeds the stated maximum weight, assistance with boarding and alighting is not usually possible. Electric vehicles that might block access to the passenger coach because of their size are not allowed on board trains.

question: Where can I get the Companion Travelcard?
answer: Full information on the Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass is available on the new page.                                             Go to the Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass

question: The lift at my station is out of order. Travel is not possible in a wheelchair. Who can I contact?
answer: The Contact Center Handicap is available to help in the case of lift issues. They will offer you an alternative travel option.

question: Why is there a ‘question mark’ in the online timetable?
answer: No accessibility data is available in the online timetable on SBB.ch for journeys that are more than 20 days in the future. Technical issues may also occur that make obtaining information temporarily impossible.

question: I travel with a special bicycle. Do I have to purchase a bike ticket?
answer: Yes. If you are using a special bicycle, such as a handbike, tandem, recumbent bike or tricycle, and you have a Disabled Passenger’s ID Card, you have to buy a bike ticket. However, bicycles with an overall length of more than two metres cannot be transported on long-distance trains.

question: Where can I submit feedback and claims?
answer: The Contact Center Handicap is available for feedback.  Please use the following form for claims.                                              Go to form for claims and complaints

question: Which stops require a shuttle service?
answer: A shuttle service to the next accessible stop is offered from stations and stops that will not be adapted until after 2023, where a structural adaptation appears excessive or where staff assistance is not possible. The shuttle service is a temporary solution and will not be used permanently.

question: Is the identity card for passengers with a disability integrated into the SwissPass?
answer: Yes, it is integrated into the SwissPass. The ID Card is now known as the Companion Travelcard.                                              Information can be found on the page ‘Travel discounts’

question: From where to where does the shuttle transport wheelchair users?
answer: As a rule: the shuttle takes you to the next accessible stop where staff assistance is guaranteed. If it makes sense, the shuttle will take you to the next transfer station.

question: What happens if the shuttle is delayed?
answer: If the shuttle is late, please call the Contact Center Handicap. The Contact Center will get in touch with the transport crew and inform you of the next steps.

question: Where can I get assistance with boarding and alighting?
answer: You can detailed information on assistance and the Contact Center Handicap under ‘Assistance in Switzerland’ and ‘Assistance for journeys abroad’ on the ‘Travel planning for accessible travel’ page.  Got to assistance for journeys in Switzerland Go to assistance for journeys abroad

question: Where can I order my GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons?
answer: You can find information about purchasing under “Help for GA Travelcard”

question: What is the cost of a GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons on the SwissPass?
answer: You can decide whether you would like to pay for your GA Travelcard annually or monthly. You can find the prices on the offer page.                                              Go to the GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons

question: How can I find accessible connections in the SBB Mobile app?
answer: You can find all the information on how to find accessible connections in the SBB Mobile app on the ‘Travel planning for accessible travel’ page.                                              Find accessible connections in the SBB Mobile app

question: Can I buy international tickets for travellers with disabilities (TCV 710 fare) or make a reservation for a wheelchair space online?
answer: As the reservation of a wheelchair space is mandatory on international trains, you can only buy tickets for travelling abroad at staffed counters or at least 24 hours before train departure from the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.).  If you do not require a wheelchair but only need a ticket and a seat, you can also purchase and/or book your tickets for travelling abroad online at SBB.ch.

question: What discounts can I get in Switzerland?
answer: On the ‘Travel discounts for passengers with a disability’ page, you can find all the travel discounts, such as the discounted GA Travelcard and the Disabled Passenger’s ID card, as well as discounts for parking in P+Rail car parks.                                              Go to ‘Travel discounts for passengers with a disability’

question: How can I find accessible connections in the SBB online timetable?
answer: You can find all the information on how to find accessible connections in the SBB online timetable on the ‘Travel planning for accessible travel’ page.                                              Find accessible connections in the SBB online timetable

question: Are connections always guaranteed when changing trains?
answer: Depending on the transfer distance and the assistance equipment involved, the minimum transfer times may not always be sufficient to ensure that you make your connecting train. Ensure sufficient time for changing trains. Please note that the Contact Center Handicap will only accept orders and schedule them if there is sufficient time to change trains.                                             Minimum transfer times in larger SBB stations

question: Can my companion use the Mobilift or the folding ramp themselves?
answer: No. Private individuals are not allowed to use the Mobilift or the folding ramp themselves. SBB cannot accept any liability in the event of damage or accidents. However, at all stations that are not support stations, private individuals are allowed to help with boarding and alighting.

question: Companion Travelcard in combination with other travel discounts.
answer: In general, the following rule applies: At least one person must be in possession of a valid ticket for travel (ticket, Day Pass, GA Travelcard, point-to-point Travelcard, modular Travelcard, but not Half Fare Travelcard without a ticket or Junior Travelcard without a ticket).  Example A. Companion Travelcard and Half Fare Travelcard = one half-price ticket is sufficient. A person with a disability holding a Companion Travelcards travelling with another person holding a Half Fare Travelcard. The passenger with the disability travels free of charge and their travelling companion with the Half Fare Card buys a half-price ticket. Example B. Companion Travelcard and GA Travelcard = the GA Travelcard is sufficient. A person with a disability holding a Companion Travelcard is travelling with another person holding a GA Travelcard. The passenger with the disability travels free of charge and their travelling companion travels using the GA Travelcard. Example C. Companion Travelcard, Half Fare Travelcard and Junior Travelcard = one half-price ticket is sufficient. One parent holds a Half Fare Travelcard. He is travelling with two children. One child has a Junior Travelcard. The other child uses a wheelchair and holds a Companion Travelcard. The parent with the Half Fare Travelcard buys a half-price ticket, the child in the wheelchair travels free of charge with the Companion Travelcard, the other child travels free of charge with the Junior Travelcard. The Junior Travelcard is only valid with a valid ticket (in this example, the ticket of the parent with the Half Fare Travelcard). Example D. Two Companion Travelcards and one Half Fare Travelcard = one person with a Companion Travelcard needs a valid ticket or travelcard.  Two people with a disability and a Companion Travelcard each are travelling together with one person who has a Half Fare Travelcard. One person with a disability travels for free and the companion with a Half Fare Travelcard purchases a ticket at half price. The second person with a disability needs an additional valid ticket or travelcard. Notice for children up until their 6th birthday: children under 6 years old cannot obtain a Companion Travelcard. This is because they always travel for free anyway. However, those accompanying them must have a valid ticket or travelcard.

question: How long is the Disabled Passenger’s ID Card (Companion Travelcard) valid for?
answer: The Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass is valid for an unlimited period.

question: Is the identity card for passengers who are blind or have a visual impairment still valid?
answer: No. Since 1 January 2024, the identity card for passengers who are blind or have a visual impairment has not been valid.

question: How much advance notice is required for organising assistance with boarding and alighting?
answer: At least one hour before boarding and alighting. You can find exceptions on the synoptic map for people with restricted mobility. Two hours before departure at stations and stops that are not barrier-free and are therefore served by a shuttle service. We recommend you book as early as possible. 24 hours for international journeys. 12 hours for registration via order form. Until 11pm for nighttime network and early morning connections (before 6am).

question: Can I take my assistance dog with me on the shuttle?
answer: Yes, assistance dogs are allowed on the shuttles.

question: Is a foreign identity card for passengers with a disability valid in Switzerland?
answer: No. A disabled person's ID card issued abroad will not entitle you to any discounts in Switzerland. Please make enquiries in your country of residence about discounts.

question: Where can I reserve wheelchair spaces in Switzerland?
answer: Unfortunately, you cannot reserve wheelchair spaces on trains in Switzerland.

question: I'm travelling with a walker-rollator. Can I request assistance from the Contact Center Handicap?
answer: Like wheelchair users, people who use walking frames can book personal assistance. However, for safety reasons you are not permitted to access the Mobilift using the walking frame. You must therefore be capable of overcoming obstacles such as individual steps, ledges and gaps without the help of the service staff.  Important: when travelling with a walker-rollator, it is necessary to plan accordingly as regards sufficient interchange time at the transfer station. We cannot guarantee that you will be able to catch the regular connecting train for every connection. Please consider this aspect when preparing your journey.

question: Can I order the shuttle myself?
answer: No, assistance must be reserved with the Contact Center Handicap. If you order a shuttle on your own, you will have to pay for the transport yourself.

question: Where do I get my identity card and how do I renew it?
answer: Information can be found on the page ‘Travel discounts’

question: I am blind. Can I buy a ticket from a ticket machine?
answer: Yes. If you are blind or visually impaired, call 0800 11 44 77 to access the SBB ticket machine helpline. Give the person on the telephone the ticket machine number, which is located above the screen in tactile lettering. The SBB ticket machine helpline will help you choose the right ticket and if requested, it will select the required product on the ticket machine for you through remote control. You can then pay for the ticket directly at the ticket machine, where it will also be printed as usual. The SBB ticket machine helpline is open every day, 24 hours a day.

question: What is the SBB Inclusive app?
answer: SBB Inclusive is a customer information app that makes travelling on public transport easier, particularly for visually impaired and blind people. The app provides visual and digital customer information for stations and long-distance trains directly in your smartphone and always shows you the information relevant to your location.                                              Go to information about the SBB Inclusive app

question: How does SBB Inclusive know where I am?
answer: Two different technologies are used to locate the user and provide them with relevant information:   At the station, GPS signals are used. If the user is at a railway station, the timetable information relevant to that station will be provided.  For coach-specific localisation whilst on board the train, the app uses beacon technology, which works via Bluetooth signals. All data is processed only in the background and SBB neither stores it nor uses it for other purposes.

question: How can those who are blind or visually impaired read the information?
answer: Blind and visually impaired people can use smartphones with voice output, in dark mode or with enlarged text, depending on their disability. The user interface of SBB Inclusive has been optimised for these features, so that the information is easy to access and navigate in line with the needs of the user.

question: What languages is SBB Inclusive available in?
answer: German, French, Italian, and English.

question: Can the app be used free of charge?
answer: Yes, the app is available free of charge from the Apple AppStore and from the Google PlayStore.

question: Is the app not working well/slowly at the railway station?
answer: Experience has shown that the app works faster and more reliably if you switch off the free SBB wireless internet at the station and use mobile data instead.

question: Why do I only receive the train information once I am on the train?
answer: Due to the range of the beacons (the train acts like a Faraday cage) the app only starts searching for the train once the user enters the coach. Experience has shown that the app works faster and more reliably if you switch off the free SBB wireless internet at the station. For the app to work, you must be connected to the internet.

question: What accessibility features does the app support?
answer: Voice over, dark mode, font magnification and transcription of audio announcements at the station.

question: Can the app also be used by people with good vision?
answer: Yes, all information is also displayed visually and appears in the familiar SBB design.

question: How reliable is the timetable information in the app?
answer: The timetable information in the app is the same shown on the digital displays at the station and on the train. SBB accepts no liability for the accuracy of the information provided. (Refer to the General Terms and Conditions).

question: Why is SBB Inclusive a stand-alone app?
answer: SBB Inclusive primarily addresses a specific user group and is optimised for their needs.

question: Why is the service not available everywhere?
answer: The beacon technology required for localisation is not yet available on all trains. It requires the installation of beacons in the body of all coaches. By the end of 2023, all long-distance trains will be fitted with beacons. SBB is currently testing equipping its regional fleet with the technology. There are currently no plans for the fleets of other transport companies to be equipped with beacons.

question: Is data protection guaranteed?
answer: You can find information on how we handle your data here:                                             Go to the SBB Inclusive Privacy Policy

question: The battery consumption of this app is higher than that of other apps. What can I do?
answer: The development team is constantly working on reducing the battery consumption of SBB Inclusive.
