Children and young people under 25 will only have to do so if their previous photo was taken more than five years ago. First-time purchasing online with an identity check. If you are purchasing a Point-to-Point Travelcard for the first time, do not already have a SwissPass and have not previously had a travelcard, you can upload your digital passport photo once the purchasing process (including the identity check) is complete.  Purchasing the travelcard for the first time at a staffed point of sale. Please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo to the counter. Changing your photo. If you would like to update your photo before the 5/10 year period has elapsed, please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo to a public transport point of sale. You can then get a new SwissPass card with the new photo for a fee of CHF 30.

question: I have forgotten my SwissPass holding a Point-to-Point Travelcard – what should I do now?
answer: If you leave your SwissPass at home or in the office you can display it very easily in the SBB Mobile app under My SwissPass (you must have your login with the linked customer number). Alternatively, you can buy a temporary card at a public transport point of sale for a fee of CHF 5 on presentation of official ID.

question: What durations of validity are available for Point-to-Point Travelcards?
answer: Point-to-Point Travelcards are available for  1 month.  12 months.

question: How does renewal work?
answer: To renew your Point-to-Point Travelcard online, use the link you receive in the renewal e-mail.  You can also renew Point-to-Point Travelcards with a validity of 1 month at SBB ticket machines.                                             Go to renewal at SBB ticket machines

question: Can I deposit my Point-to-Point Travelcard or give it back and have it refunded?
answer: You cannot deposit your Point-to-Point Travelcard. If you wish to cancel your Point-to-Point Travelcard within the duration of validity and give it back, you can have it refunded at a public transport point of sale or by phoning the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). The refund is calculated as a percentage of the number of days used. A deductible is also charged.                                             Go to the refund conditions as per Tariff 600.9 Refunds, Chapter 4 (in German, French and Italian)                         Link opens in new window.

question: My SwissPass holding a Point-to-Point Travelcard has been lost or damaged – what can I do?
answer: No problem, order a replacement SwissPass for CHF 30. We will also be happy to serve you at a staffed point of sale.                                              Order a replacement SwissPass

question: Does the Point-to-Point Travelcard also give me discount on day trips with RailAway?
answer: Yes, as long as the whole route is covered, you can benefit from at least 10% discount.                                             Discover ideas for excursions

question: Which documents do I need to purchase a Point-to-Point Travelcard for the first time?
answer: Purchasing online with a SwissPass. You will need the following documents for your first online purchase with SwissPass.  Debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne), Twint. (The credit card must be in the same name as the contracting party.) Passport or ID card.  When buying online, you can enter details for the following types of ID: passports and ID cards issued in Switzerland, Germany, Austria, France, Italy or Liechtenstein.   Purchasing online for the first time with an identity check. When purchasing with the identity check, you can only buy a Point-to-Point Travelcard for yourself. You will need:  a smartphone with a camera. a debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne), Twint. a recent, high-quality, digital passport photo. a passport or ID card.  List of the accepted forms of IDLink opens in new window. Questions on the identity checkLink opens in new window. Purchasing at a public transport point of sale.  To purchase for the first time at a public transport point of sale, you need a recent analogue or digital passport photo and the passport/ID card for yourself or the other person (for example, if you are purchasing a Point-to-Point Travelcard for your child as a parent or for another person). Purchasing at SBB ticket machines (1-month Point-to-Point Travelcards only). You need a SwissPass to purchase a Point-to-Point Travelcard at an SBB ticket machine for the first time.                                              Buy monthly travelcards at an SBB ticket machine

question: How does the renewal work?
answer: For online renewal of the Regional Travelcard for 1 month or 12 months, use the link you receive in the renewal email. You can renew Regional Travelcards with a validity of 1 month online without link, on a mobile device, at ticket machines and at a staffed public transport point of sale in your fare network.                                              More information on the renewal

question: How can I buy a Regional Travelcard?
answer: First-time purchasing online (only for 1 month and 12 months). When purchasing online, the most important thing is your customer number in the format 000-000-000-0. If you have or had a SwissPass or a public transport travelcard in the last five years, you can find this number on your SwissPass card and use it to purchase your Regional Travelcard online. If you used to have a travelcard but have forgotten the customer number, you can find out what it is by going to a public transport point of sale or phoning the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). To make sure you receive the right offer for adults, young people or children when purchasing online, please enter the relevant customer number.                                             Buy Regional Travelcard online now                                                                You may also want to know: if you wish to buy the Regional Travelcard for another person (f. ex. a child), you can do so, as long as you and the other person hold SwissPass cards with a linked SwissPass login. To buy for the other person, select Purchase a travelcard for another person during the purchasing process. Note: a SwissPass login is linked with SBB.ch if the customer number is stored in your profile on SBB.ch. After signing in, click on your initials, then on Profile and then on Update details in the Personal details tile. If the customer number is displayed in the form 000-000-000-0, it means it is linked.                                             Link customer number                                                                Purchasing online with the identity check (only for 1 month and 12 months). If you don’t have a travelcard or a SwissPass, you can still buy your new Regional Travelcard online. If you are buying a travelcard for the first time, we need to verify your identity. This identity check takes place online – you will need your passport or ID card and a smartphone with a camera. You will also need a recent, high-quality, digital passport photo. Online purchase with an identity check is not possible for other persons                                             Questions on the identity check                         Link opens in new window.                                       Purchase for the first time at SBB ticket machines (for 1 month). If you have a SwissPass, you can also purchase a Regional Travelcard for 1 month at SBB ticket machines.                                              How to purchase a monthly travelcard at SBB ticket machines                                                                Purchase at a staffed public transport point of sale. Of course, you can also purchase all Regional Travelcards at a staffed public transport point of sale. Please bring your SwissPass (if you have one) and your passport or ID card with you. If you don’t yet have a SwissPass, you will need to bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo and your passport or ID card. If you are purchasing on behalf of someone else (e.g. for your child), then please bring the documents for this person. Regional Travelcard for 7 days. The travelcard is issued in paper form. You can get it at a public transport point of sale or at a ticket machine in your fare network. Important: if you do not hold or need a SwissPass card, you still need to bring a passport/ID card and a high-quality up-to-date passport photo with you when ordering for the first time (only possible at a point of sale). This is needed to produce a basic card for your travelcard.

question: When should I buy a Regional Travelcard and when a Point-to-Point Travelcard and when a Modular Travelcard?
answer: If the whole of your chosen route lies within one fare network, you will automatically receive a Regional Travelcard.  Point-to-Point Travelcards are only available in regions without a fare network or, when you are travelling beyond the limits of one fare network. If you regularly travel between fare networks or outside a fare network and would like to use local transport, the Modular Travelcard is an ideal solution.  It is worth noting that purchasing a GA Travelcard is the best option beyond a certain distance.

question: My SwissPass holding a Regional Travelcard has been lost or damaged – what should I do?
answer: No problem, order a replacement SwissPass for CHF 30. We are also happy to help you at a staffed point of sale.                                             Order a replacement SwissPass

question: How long does it take to receive my Regional Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: Already have a SwissPass? Your Regional Travelcard will be integrated on the SwissPass from its first day of validity.  This is your first SwissPass? Your Regional Travelcard on the SwissPass will be delivered by post within around 10 days. If you would like your travelcard to be valid earlier, we can provide a temporary SwissPass. If you purchase online, you can print it out as a PDF.

question: Can I deposit my Regional Travelcard or hand it back and have it refunded?
answer: You cannot deposit your Regional Travelcard. If you wish to cancel and give back your Regional Travelcard within the duration of validity, you can do so at a public transport point of sale or by phoning the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). The refund will be made pro rata based on the number of unused days. A deductible is also charged.                                             Go to the refund conditions as per Tariff 600.9 Refunds, Chapter 4 (in German)                         Link opens in new window.

question: Which validity periods are available for Regional Travelcards?
answer: Regional Travelcards are available for  7 days (in paper form, only available on some fare networks). 1 month on the SwissPass. 12 months on the SwissPass.

question: What do I need to consider when taking my photo?
answer: Requirements. For the travelcard on the SwissPass, you need to provide a recent analogue or digital passport photo which fulfils the following criteria:  Taken from the front. Eyes open and not covered. Plain background. Even lighting (no shadows). Clear with high contrast. Black and white or colour. Approx. size 35mm × 45mm. Analogue passport photo: only original prints, no scans or photos printed out on paper. Digital passport photo: unedited, min. image size 200 × 250 pixels; in .JPG or .JPEG format with a maximum size of 4MB.  Purchasing a Regional Travelcard online for the first time. If you already have a SwissPass or used to have another public transport travelcard, we will use the same photo for your new travelcard. In this case, adults will only need to provide a new photo if the previous one was taken more than ten years ago. Children and young people under 25 will only have to do so if their previous photo was taken more than five years ago. If you are purchasing a Regional Travelcard for the first time, do not already have a SwissPass and have not previously had a travelcard, you can upload your digital passport photo once the purchasing process (including the identity check) is complete.  Purchasing the travelcard for the first time at a staffed point of sale. Please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo to the counter. Changing your photo. If you would like to update your photo before the 5/10 year period has elapsed, please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo to a public transport point of sale. You can then get a new SwissPass card with the new photo for a fee of CHF 30.

question: Are Regional Travelcards cheaper with a Half Fare Travelcard?
answer: No, you cannot combine a Regional Travelcard with a Half Fare Travelcard.

question: Which payment methods can I use to pay for my Regional Travelcard?
answer: Purchasing online (Regional Travelcard for one month and 12 months). When purchasing online, you can pay by credit card, PostFinance Card, Reka Card, Twint or via invoice. Purchasing at SBB ticket machines (only Regional Travelcards for one month).                                             Go to payment methods at SBB ticket machines                                                                Payment by invoice. We will send you the invoice together with a payment slip in the post. Please note:  Your order must be placed at least ten days before your travelcard validity begins. Otherwise your payment by invoice cannot be processed and will be returned. We will send you the invoice separately – i.e. not together with your SwissPass card. You must pay the invoice before the first day that your travelcard is valid, otherwise you will receive a payment reminder.  Purchasing at a staffed public transport point of sale (all Regional Travelcards). When purchasing at a staffed point of sale, the following payment methods are available to you: cash, vouchers, Reka Check, Reka Rail, Twint, debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne). Payment by credit card (please keep in mind the limit on your card). You can pay for your new travelcard with the following credit cards:  Visa (incl. prepaid cards) MasterCard (incl. prepaid cards) American Express Diners Club International JCB MyOne  Please note:  The credit card must be in the same name as the contracting party. The credit card will be charged once the order has been received.

question: What discounts do Regional Travelcards offer?
answer: If you buy your Regional Travelcard for 12 months, you will receive a reduction of up to 3 months on the monthly price. Children and young people under 25 benefit from attractive discounts. Further discounts available depend on the fare network.                                               Go to all fare networks

question: Can I get discounts on RailAway day trips with my Regional Travelcard?
answer: Yes, as long as the entire route is covered, you can benefit from a discount of at least 10% or added value for numerous leisure time activities.                                             Discover ideas for excursions

question: Which documents do I need to purchase a Regional Travelcard for the first time?
answer: Purchasing online with a SwissPass (1-month and 12-month Regional Travelcards only). You will need the following documents for your first online purchase with SwissPass.  Debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne), Twint. (The credit card must be in the same name as the contracting party.) Passport or ID card.  When buying online, you can enter details for the following types of ID: passports and ID cards issued in Switzerland, Germany, Austria, France, Italy or Liechtenstein.   Purchasing online for the first time with an identity check (1-month and 12-month Regional Travelcards only). When purchasing with the identity check, you can only buy a Regional Travelcard for yourself. You will need:  a smartphone with a camera. a debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne), Twint. a recent, high-quality, digital passport photo. a passport or ID card.  List of the accepted forms of IDLink opens in new window.  Questions on the identity check Link opens in new window. Purchasing at a public transport point of sale (all Regional Travelcards). To purchase for the first time at a public transport point of sale, you need a recent analogue or digital passport photo and the passport/ID card for yourself or the other person (for example, if you are purchasing a Point-to-Point Travelcard for your child as a parent or for another person). Purchasing at SBB ticket machines (1-month Regional Travelcards only). You need a SwissPass to purchase a Regional Travelcard at an SBB ticket machine for the first time.                                              Buy monthly travelcards at an SBB ticket machine

question: Can Regional and Point-to-Point Travelcards be combined?
answer: If you regularly commute between fare networks or beyond a fare network and wish to use local services within it, the Modular Travelcard is an ideal solution.                                             Go to the Modular Travelcard

question: I have forgotten my SwissPass holding a Regional Travelcard – what should I do?
answer: If you leave your SwissPass at home or in the office you can display it very easily in the SBB Mobile app under My SwissPass (you must have your login with the linked customer number). Alternatively, you can buy a card with temporary validity for a fee of CHF 5 from a public transport point of sale upon presentation of official ID.

question: How long is a Modular Travelcard valid for?
answer: You can choose a validity period of one month or twelve months.

question: When does it make sense to buy a Modular Travelcard?
answer: If you  regularly travel between two integrated fare networks. regularly use local public transport in an integrated fare network and commute to somewhere outside of this fare network.

question: What classes of travel are Modular Travelcards available for?
answer: Adults aged 25 or over can buy Modular Travelcards for 1st and 2nd class. Children and young people aged at least 6 and under 25 can buy 2nd class Modular Travelcards at a reduced price. If children and young people want to travel in 1st class with the Modular Travelcard, they pay the adult price.

question: My SwissPass with the integrated Modular Travelcard has been lost or damaged – what can I do now?
answer: No problem, you can order a replacement SwissPass online for CHF 30. We will also be pleased to assist you at a staffed point of sale.                                              Order a SwissPass replacement card

question: What do I need to consider when taking my photo?
answer: Purchasing for the first time at a staffed public transport point of sale. Since the Modular Travelcards integrated on a SwissPass card, we require a recent analogue or digital passport photo. Your photo will be stored electronically for a maximum of ten years (or five years for children and young people under 25). Requirements. For the travelcard on the SwissPass, you need to provide a recent analogue or digital passport photo which fulfils the following criteria:  Taken from the front. Eyes open and not covered. Plain background. Even lighting (no shadows). Clear with high contrast. Black and white or colour. Approx. size 35mm × 45mm. Analogue passport photo: only original prints, no scans or photos printed out on paper. Digital passport photo: unedited, min. image size 200 × 250 pixels; in .JPG or .JPEG format with a maximum size of 4MB.

question: When do I buy a Point-to-Point Travelcard and when a Regional Travelcard?
answer: If the route you require is within a fare network, you should purchase a regional travelcard rather than a Modular Travelcard.  If you travel regularly on a certain route only, the Point-to-point Travelcard is the ideal solution. To the Regional Travelcard To the Point-to-Point Travelcard

question: Which zones can I combine?
answer: We have created an overview of the locations and the corresponding zones.                                             To the Modular Travelcard zone plans

question: Is a Modular Travelcard cheaper than a GA Travelcard?
answer: No, not in every case. If the distance is sufficiently long, purchasing a GA Travelcard can be worthwhile.                                             To the GA Travelcard

question: Can I buy a Modular Travelcard even if I don’t hold a SwissPass?
answer: If you don’t have a SwissPass, purchase your Modular Travelcard from a staffed public transport point of sale. Please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo and your passport or ID card. You will then receive your Modular Travelcard together with the SwissPass.

question: Who can buy a Modular Travelcard?
answer: Modular Travelcards are available for travellers from the age of 6.

question: How do I buy a Modular Travelcard?
answer: You need a SwissPass to buy a Modular Travelcard.                                              How to get a SwissPass                                                                If you already hold a SwissPass, you can purchase the Modular Travelcard at a public transport public of sale or by phone from the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). The Modular Travelcard is held on your SwissPass.

question: Can I deposit my Modular Travelcard or hand it in and have it refunded?
answer: You can’t deposit your Modular Travelcard. If you wish to give back your Modular Travelcard within the period of validity and hand it in, you can obtain a refund from a public transport point of sale or by phoning the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.). The refund will be made pro rata based on the number of unused days. A deductible is also charged.                                             To the refund conditions governed by Tariff 600.9 Refunds, Chapter 4                         Link opens in new window.

question: I’ve forgotten my SwissPass with the integrated Modular Travelcard – what should I do now?
answer: If you leave your SwissPass at home or in the office, you can easily display it in the SBB Mobile app under ‘My SwissPass’ (requirement: login with linked customer number). Alternatively, you can buy a temporary card at a public transport point of sale for a fee of CHF 5 on presentation of official ID.

question: How do I renew my Modular Travelcard?
answer: Modular Travelcard for one month. You can renew it at any public transport point of sale, at a ticket machine or online. To renew online, use the link you receive in the renewal e-mail. Modular Travelcard for twelve months. You can renew it at any public transport point of sale or online. To renew online, use the link you receive in the renewal e-mail.

question: How long does it take to receive my Modular Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: Already have a SwissPass? Your Modular Travelcard will be valid on the SwissPass from its first day of validity.  This is your first SwissPass? Your Modular Travelcard on the SwissPass will be delivered by post within around 10 days. If you would like your travelcard to be valid earlier, we can provide a temporary SwissPass.

question: How will I receive my Leisure Travelcard?
answer: The Leisure Travelcard will be integrated onto your SwissPass.                                             Here’s how you can get a SwissPass

question: What is a Leisure Travelcard?
answer: Do you often go on excursions with public transport in your free time? Combine the Leisure Travelcard with the Half-Fare Travelcard and enjoy 20 or 30 days of unlimited travel per year on all SBB trains and most other railways as well as trams, buses, postbuses and boats.  The Leisure Travelcard:  is only available on the SwissPass and is managed via your personal SwissPass account. is valid only in combination with a Half Fare Travelcard. is valid on the GA area of validity. You can purchase connecting tickets at a reduced fare when you use the Half Fare Travelcard. is personal and non-transferable. cannot be deposited.

question: Where can I deactivate leisure days that I have already activated?
answer: Activated leisure days may be deactivated at your account on swisspass.chLink opens in new window. before the start of validity, at the latest by 23.59 on the previous day.

question: What happens to leisure days that I don’t use?
answer: Unused leisure days are forfeited and cannot be carried over to the following year. Any partial refund is dependent on the number of days already used.                                             Go to information about reimbursements

question: How much does the Leisure Travelcard cost?
answer: The price of the Leisure Travelcard depends on which version you purchase (20 or 30 days, 1st or 2nd class). You can find the current prices on the page dedicated to the Leisure Travelcard.                                             To the Leisure Travelcard

question: How long is the Leisure Travelcard valid for?
answer: The Leisure Travelcard is valid for one year.

question: Can I also travel in 1st class with a 2nd class Leisure Travelcard?
answer: You can buy route-specific class upgrades, Supersaver Class Upgrades at a discounted price or 1-day class upgrades for your 2nd class Leisure Travelcard with a valid Half Fare Travelcard.                                             To the class upgrade

question: How do I use the Leisure Travelcard?
answer: If you would like to use a leisure day, you must activate the relevant day yourself at swisspass.chLink opens in new window. in your personal account before your journey. You can get help with this at staffed public transport points of sale.

question: Where can I get the Leisure Travelcard?
answer: With the SwissPass, you can get the Leisure Travelcard at numerous staffed public transport points of sale or conveniently online.                                             To the Leisure Travelcard on the SwissPass

question: Does the Leisure Travelcard get you discounts on day trips with RailAway?
answer: Yes. With tickets for public transport, you can enjoy at least 10% discount or added value for numerous leisure experience.                                             To the day trips

question: Can I cancel the Leisure Travelcard and will it be refunded?
answer: Yes. For the refund, CHF 75 (2nd class) or CHF 127 (1st class) is deducted for each leisure day that has been used, which corresponds to the price of a Day Pass for the Half Fare Travelcard. You receive the remaining amount minus the customary deductible of 10 Swiss francs. If you would like to cancel your Leisure Travelcard, please go to a public transport point of sale, or call the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.)                                             Go to information about reimbursements

question: Where can I activate my leisure days?
answer: You must activate your leisure days yourself on swisspass.chLink opens in new window. before you travel. To do so, you will need a personal SwissPass account – if you do not already have one, swisspass.chLink opens in new window.. If you would like to activate leisure days before the first day of validity for your Leisure Travelcard or if you need any help, please contact a staffed public transport point of sale or call the SBB Contact Center on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.)

question: I’ve lost my Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass – what should I do?
answer: Have you lost your SwissPass or has it been damaged? You can order a SwissPass replacement card for CHF 30 online at SBB.ch, via the SBB Contact Center or at a staffed public transport point of sale.                                             Order your SwissPass replacement card here

question: I’m travelling and have forgotten my Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass – what happens now?
answer: If you’ve left your SwissPass at home or at the office, you can display it easily in the SBB Mobile app in the Tickets & SwissPass tile (you must have a login with a linked customer number to do so). Alternatively, for a fee of CHF 5 and upon presentation of an official ID, we can issue you with a temporary card, available at any ticket counter. Further information on travel discounts  Further questions about travel with reduced mobility

question: Which documents do I need for a Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: For orders with SwissPass. You only require the completed and signed medical certificate.  For orders without SwissPass.  A current original passport photo for orders by post and a digital photo for online orders. The copy of an official identity document (passport/ID card) for orders by post and as a scan or clearly visible photo for online orders. The signed medical certificate for orders by post or as a scan or clearly visible photo for online orders.

question: What do I need to consider when taking my photo?
answer: When placing the first order for a Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass. If you already have a SwissPass or used to have another public transport travelcard, we will use the same photo for your new travelcard. In this case, adults will only need to provide a new photo if the previous one was taken more than ten years ago. Children and young people under 25 will only have to do so if their previous photo was taken more than five years ago.  When placing a first order without SwissPass. You will need to submit an original, high resolution passport photo taken recently. Your photo will be stored electronically for a maximum of ten years (or five years for children and young people under 25).  Requirements. For your travelcard on the SwissPass, you need to provide a passport photo that meets the following criteria:  Taken from the front. Eyes open and not covered. Plain background. Even lighting (no shadows). Clear with high contrast. Black and white or colour. Approx. size 35mm × 45mm. Original photo: no scans or photos printed out on paper. Digital photo: unedited, min. image size 200 × 250 pixels; in .JPG or .JPEG format with a maximum size of 4MB.  Order by post.   Please write your first name and surname in block capitals on the back of the photo. Please attach the photo to the order form in the space indicated.  Online order.  Upload the digital passport photo in the upload field. Change photo. If you would like a new photo before the expiry of the deadline (10 years for people over the age of 25, 5 years for people under the age of 25), bring a current original passport photo in high resolution to a public transport point of sale. You can then get a new SwissPass card with the new photo for a fee of CHF 30.

question: How do I order the Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: You can order the Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass by post or online. It cannot be ordered at the counter. You can order the Companion Travelcard for yourself or a person with a disability (e.g. as a parent, representative, helper, guardian etc.). It is important to note that the SwissPass and SwissPass login of the person with a disability travelling are always used.                                              Order by post:   Download the ‘medical certificate for SwissPass (PDF, 208 KB)Link opens in new window. (PDF, 208 KB)’. Complete all points on the computer (except for point 4). Print out the completed form. (Alternatively you can print out the PDF and then complete it by hand.) Arrange for point 4 to be completed and signed by the doctor. Then sign the medical certificate yourself. If you do NOT have a SwissPass: attach a passport photo. If you do NOT have a SwissPass: attach a copy of the ID document (passport/ID card). Send the medical certificate and the passport photo and copy of ID by post to the SBB Contact Centre, Companion Card, P.O. Box 176, 3900 Brig                                          Downloads.                                            Medical certificate for SwissPass (PDF, 208 KB)                                                                                                                            Download                 The link destination will be opened in an external application or a new window (PDF, 208 KB)             Link opens in new window.                                                      Go to the photo instructions Online order with SwissPass and SwissPass login.  Download the ‘medical certificate for SwissPass (PDF, 208 KB)Link opens in new window. (PDF, 208 KB)’. Complete all points on the computer (except for point 4). Print out the completed form. (Alternatively you can print out the PDF and then complete it by hand.) Arrange for point 4 to be completed and signed by the doctor. Then sign the medical certificate yourself. Scan the medical certificate or photograph it so that everything is clearly legible. Open the online order form.  Log in with your SwissPass login (if ordering for yourself. Otherwise use the login details of the person with a disability travelling). Upload the medical certificate. Click on ‘Send’.                                         Downloads.                                            Medical certificate for SwissPass (PDF, 208 KB)                                                                                                                            Download                 The link destination will be opened in an external application or a new window (PDF, 208 KB)             Link opens in new window.                                                      Go to the online order form Help with the SwissPass login                                             Online order without SwissPass.   Download the ‘medical certificate for SwissPass (PDF, 208 KB)Link opens in new window. (PDF, 208 KB)’. Complete all points on the computer (except for point 4). Print out the completed form. (Alternatively you can print out the PDF and then complete it by hand.) Arrange for point 4 to be completed and signed by the doctor. Then sign the medical certificate yourself. Scan the medical certificate or photograph it so that everything is clearly legible. Open the online order form. Select the ‘I don’t have a SwissPass card’ option. Upload the digital passport photo. Upload the scan or photo of an identification document (passport/ID card). Upload the certificate. Enter your details. Click on ‘Send’.                                         Downloads.                                            Medical certificate for SwissPass (PDF, 208 KB)                                                                                                                            Download                 The link destination will be opened in an external application or a new window (PDF, 208 KB)             Link opens in new window.                                                      Go to the photo instructions Go to the online order form

question: How long does it take before I get my Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: Do you already have a SwissPass? The Companion Travelcard is activated directly on your SwissPass. As soon as this has been completed, you will receive notification via SMS or e-mail. Is it your first SwissPass? The SwissPass card will be sent to you by post. The SwissPass will be delivered within approx. ten days after processing. You will also receive notification via SMS text or e-mail as soon as the Companion Travelcard has been activated on your SwissPass and you can then display the Companion Travelcard on the SwissPass.

question: What do I do if I don’t want the SwissPass card for my child?
answer: The Junior Travelcard is now only available on the SwissPass. The standard range is available if you travel with children without the Junior Travelcard – for example, the Day Pass Children for CHF 19 (2nd class) or CHF 33 (1st class). The Day Pass Children is valid across the GA Travelcard area of validity.                                             Go to the GA Travelcard area of validity

question: I am travelling in Switzerland as a tourist. Does my child also need a Junior Travelcard?
answer: No. If you want your child to travel for free, you have the option of buying one of the Swiss Travel System products (e.g. the Swiss Travel Pass). Your child will then receive a Swiss Family Card for free.                                             Go to the Swiss Travel System products                                                                If you decide not to use a Swiss Travel System product, you can buy a Swiss Junior Travelcard to allow children to travel for free at any staffed point of sale. You receive it in paper form with a validity of 30 days for the price of CHF 30. If you are travelling in 2nd class and are only making a few journeys or travelling with your child for one day, the following further alternatives are available:  the Day Pass Children for CHF 19 (valid for one calendar day in the GA Travelcard area of validity). A half-price Point-to-Point Ticket for each journey (worthwhile for journeys for which the ticket costs less than CHF 19 per day).                                              Go to the GA Travelcard area of validity

question: Is the child’s Junior Travelcard linked to the parents’ SwissPass?
answer: Yes. The Junior Travelcard is linked to the parents’ SwissPass. However, the child remains the holder of the travelcard.

question: The validity of the Junior Travelcard is no longer printed directly on the SwissPass card. Where can I check it?
answer: On swisspass.ch, you can see the validity of travelcards at any time – both in the child’s account and in the account of the registered parents. You can also scan your child’s SwissPass at a ticket machine using the scan function to check its validity.

question: Where is the Junior Travelcard valid?
answer: The Junior Travelcard has the same area of validity as the Half Fare Travelcard.                                             Go to the Junior Travelcard area of validity

question: I am only in Switzerland temporarily (up to max. 30 days). Does my child also need a SwissPass card?
answer: No. You can receive a paper Junior Travelcard for your children with a validity of 30 days for CHF 30. Available from any staffed point of sale. If you are travelling in 2nd class and are only making a few journeys or only travelling with the child for one day, there are alternatives:  The Day Pass Children for CHF 19 (valid for one calendar day in the GA Travelcard area of validity). A half-price Point-to-Point Ticket for each journey (worthwhile for journeys for which the ticket costs less than CHF 19 per day).                                              Go to the GA Travelcard area of validity

question: How do I renew the Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass card?
answer: Online renewal. If no changes are needed, renew the Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass conveniently online (you do not need a login). Here’s how it works.  Parent 1 (the first person entered) receives a reminder by e-mail. Click on the link in the e-mail and renew the Junior Travelcard.  Would you rather receive an SMS text than an e-mail? On swisspass.ch, you can change the contact channels under ‘Contact channel’ as Parent 1.                                             Go to ‘Contact channel’ settings on swisspass.ch                         Link opens in new window.                                       Please note: the free Junior Travelcard provided for the third child and further children must always be renewed at a staffed station as before. Reason: sales staff check that you have a right to the free card manually every year. Please bring both the other Junior Travelcards with you (on the children’s SwissPass cards). Alternatively, buy a Junior Travelcard for CHF 30 per year. Renewal at ticket machines. Alternatively, you can also renew the Junior Travelcard at ticket machines. Use the scan function to do so.

question: Do I receive two copies of the Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: No. Each child gets their own SwissPass card. Notes. The Junior Travelcard/Children’s Co-Travelcard can be checked both on the child’s personal SwissPass card/SwissPass Mobile and on the SwissPass card/SwissPass Mobile of the accompanying parent or companion. It is therefore enough simply to present the SwissPass/SwissPass Mobile belonging to the accompanying parent or companion when the Junior Travelcard/Children’s Co-Travelcard is checked.  Important: Only the Junior Travelcard/Children’s Co-Travelcard can be checked via the SwissPass/SwissPass Mobile of the accompanying parent or companion. All other travelcards can still only be checked via the child’s personal SwissPass.

question: Can a child also use the Junior Travelcard to travel without being accompanied by a parent?
answer: No. The Junior Travelcard is only valid if the child is accompanied by a parent. The parent must have a valid ticket for 1st or 2nd class.

question: Will I be notified of the travelcard’s expiry?
answer: We will inform the first parent entered as follows:  6 weeks before the last day of validity of the travelcard, we send information telling you that it will soon expire – by SMS text or e-mail depending on your preference. The message will contain a link which you can click on to renew your travelcard conveniently. Shortly before / after the first and last day of validity, we will send another reminder – by SMS text or e-mail depending on your preference.

question: What can I do if I have lost the Junior Travelcard or forgotten to bring it with me?
answer: Junior Travel Card on the SwissPass.  Tip: The Junior Travelcard can also be checked via the SwissPass or SwissPass Mobile of the accompanying parent (e.g. in the SBB Mobile app). To ensure ticket inspection is possible via the app, the accompanying parent must have a SwissPass login and have linked it to the app. You will find instructions on how to do this on the general questions on logins page.                                              Go to the SwissPass login                                                                If your SwissPass card is lost or stolen, you can order a new one. This costs CHF 30.                                              Order a replacement SwissPass card

question: Where can I buy the Junior Travelcard?
answer: Initial purchase on the SwissPass card. As a parent, you can buy a Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass at any staffed public transport point of sale. Read the questions in the Photo and Documents sections.

question: Who is the travelcard holder for the Junior Travelcard?
answer: The holder of the travelcard is always the child.

question: Can I buy a second SwissPass card?
answer: No. Each person can hold only one active SwissPass card. If for example the child loses their SwissPass card and a replacement SwissPass card was therefore issued, the first card is blocked and can no longer be used. That is how we prevent misuse of the first card.

question: What do I have to take into account regarding the photo?
answer: Requirements. For the travelcard on the SwissPass, you need to provide a recent passport photo of the child which fulfils the following criteria:  Taken from the front. Eyes open and not covered. Plain background. Even lighting (no shadows). Clear with high contrast. Black and white or colour. Approx. size 35mm × 45mm. Analogue passport photo: only original prints, no scans or photos printed out on paper. Digital passport photo: unedited, min. image size 200 × 250 pixels; in .JPG or .JPEG format with a maximum size of 4MB.  Purchasing the travelcard for the first time at a staffed point of sale. Please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo to the counter. For renewal of a Junior Travelcard online. If your child already holds a SwissPass, the same photo will be used. Children and young people aged at least 6 and under 25 only need a new photo if the current photo was taken more than five years ago. Changing the photo on the SwissPass. If you would like to change the child’s photo for the SwissPass before the end of the five-year period, please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo to a public transport point of sale. You – or your child – will then receive a new SwissPass card with the new photo. This costs CHF 30.

question: Which documents do I need to purchase a Junior Travelcard for the first time on the SwissPass?
answer: For an initial purchase of the Junior Travelcard, bring official ID for both the child and the parent(s) or your family booklet. To obtain the free Junior Travelcard for the third child (and all further children), please bring both of the other Junior Travelcards (on the children’s SwissPass cards).

question: Can I exchange the Junior Travelcard or have it refunded?
answer: No, exchanges and refunds are not possible for the Junior Travelcard.

question: How can I set up a separate login for swisspass.ch for my child?
answer: If you want to set up a separate customer account for your child, you need a separate e-mail address for the child. If you have your own customer account on swisspass.ch, you cannot use your e-mail address. Every person with a SwissPass needs their own e-mail address. You will find instructions on how to do this on the general questions on logins page.                                              Go to the SwissPass login                                                                However, you can give your e-mail address for correspondence so that you receive all the relevant information. Go to ‘Customer data’ on swisspass.ch using your child’s login and untick ‘Use login e-mail as contact address’ under ‘Correspondence’. Enter your email address instead.  Tip:  Select ‘No’ under ‘Contact channel’ for the SwissPass newsletter so that you do not receive the newsletter twice (if you have a customer account yourself on swisspass.ch and you have entered your e-mail address as the correspondence address for the child). In the profile on SBB.ch. Untick the box about receiving information from SBB under ‘Notifications’ so that the SBB newsletter is not sent to your e-mail address twice (if your e-mail address is also given as the correspondence address for your child).

question: What is the Junior Travelcard?
answer: The Junior Travelcard allows children aged at least 6 and under 16 to travel for free for a whole year throughout Switzerland with a parent. The accompanying parent must hold a valid ticket for 2nd or 1st class (e.g. a ticket, GA Travelcard, Point-to-Point Travelcard); the child can travel in either class for free. The Junior Travelcard is free from the third child. The Junior Travelcard is issued on the SwissPass.                                             Go to the Junior Travelcard

question: Can I show the Junior Travelcard on my smartphone via the SBB Mobile app?
answer: Yes. To display the child’s SwissPass card via the SwissPass Mobile function (e.g. in the SBB Mobile app), the child needs their own SwissPass login. The Junior Travelcard/Children’s Co-Travelcard can also be checked on the SwissPass Mobile of the parent or companion who is travelling with the child.  To ensure ticket inspection is possible via the app, the child and/or the accompanying parent must have a SwissPass login and have linked it to the app. You will find instructions on how to do this on the general questions on logins page.  Go to the SwissPass login More information on SwissPass Mobile

question: For which age group and for how long is the Junior Travelcard valid?
answer: The Junior Travelcard is valid for children aged 6 or over and under 16 for one year or until the day before their 16th birthday (at the latest).

question: Does my child need their own login for swisspass.ch?
answer: No. If you always just show the SwissPass card, a separate login is not needed. The child only needs a login if they want to show the Junior Travelcard in an app (e.g. SBB Mobile).

question: Will the child receive their own SwissPass card?
answer: Yes. Every child who holds a public transport travelcard (e.g. Junior Travelcard, Children’s Co-Travelcard, Regional Travelcard) on the SwissPass has their own SwissPass card. All public transport travelcards are then stored on this card.

question: What happens during ticket inspection?
answer: During the ticket inspection, either the child presents their own SwissPass card or you as the parent show your SwissPass card. The Junior Travelcard can be checked on both the child’s and the parent’s SwissPass.  The passenger attendant will check whether the right person is travelling with the child. The first names, surnames and photographs of the permitted companions or children are shown to the train crew via the ticket checking device. This information is then checked against the official ID or SwissPass presented. You must also show your own ticket or travelcard (separate ticket, GA Travelcard etc.) at the same time. If the child and/or the parents use SwissPass Mobile (e.g. in the SBB Mobile app), the Junior Travelcard can also be checked on a smartphone.                                              Go to SwissPass Mobile

question: What payment methods can I use to pay for a Junior Travelcard?
answer: Initial purchase on the SwissPass card. For an initial purchase, the following payment methods are available at staffed points of sale: cash, vouchers, Reka Check, Reka Rail, Twint, debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne). Renew (my child’s Junior Travelcard is already on the SwissPass). If you renew the Junior Travelcard online, you can pay with a credit card, PostFinance card, Reka card, by monthly invoicing or with Twint. If you renew the Junior Travelcard at a staffed point of sale, the following payment methods are available: cash, vouchers, Reka Check, Reka Rail, Twint, debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne).

question: Why does the child receive their own SwissPass card?
answer: The Junior Travelcard is a personal travelcard and is therefore only stored on the child’s own personal SwissPass. Other travelcards: as the child grows older, it is increasingly likely that they will purchase other personal travelcards for travelling independently. A large number of children under 16 already have their own SwissPass card. Additional advantages: the child will also be able to benefit from other advantages, for example partner services, such as ski passes or entrance tickets, which can be stored on the SwissPass card. Sustainability: the card can be used for five years and can hold numerous different offers and products.

question: How much does the Junior Travelcard cost?
answer: The Junior Travelcard costs CHF 30. One Junior Travelcard is issued per child; it can be used by both parents. The Junior Travelcard is free from the third child.

question: How long does it take for the child to receive the Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: Does your child already have a SwissPass card? The Junior Travelcard is integrated on the SwissPass from its first day of validity. Is it your child’s first SwissPass card? The Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass will be delivered by post within around ten days. If you need the Junior Travelcard before then, you can receive a temporary SwissPass from us. Renewing the Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass. The Junior Travelcard on the SwissPass is valid from the first day of validity.

question: Where is the Children’s Co-Travelcard valid?
answer: The Children’s Co-Travelcard has the same area of validity as the Half Fare Travelcard.                                             Go to the Children’s Co-Travelcard area of validity

question: Do I receive two copies of the Children’s Co-Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: No. Each child receives their own SwissPass card. Notes. The Junior Travelcard/Children’s Co-Travelcard can be checked both on the child’s personal SwissPass card/SwissPass Mobile and on the SwissPass card/SwissPass Mobile of the accompanying parent or companion. It is therefore enough simply to present the SwissPass/SwissPass Mobile belonging to the accompanying parent or companion when the Junior Travelcard/Children’s Co-Travelcard is checked.  To ensure ticket inspection is possible via the app, the child and/or the accompanying companion must have a SwissPass login and have linked it to the app. You will find instructions on how to do this on the general questions on logins page.                                              Go to the SwissPass login                                                                Important: Only the Junior Travelcard/Children’s Co-Travelcard can be checked via the SwissPass/SwissPass Mobile of the accompanying parent or companion. All other travelcards can still only be checked via the child’s personal SwissPass.

question: How long does it take for the child to receive the Children’s Co-Travelcard on the SwissPass?
answer: Does your child already have a SwissPass card? The Children’s Co-Travelcard is integrated on the SwissPass from its first day of validity. Is this your child’s first SwissPass card? The Children’s Co-Travelcard on the SwissPass will be delivered within around ten days by post. If you need the Children’s Co-Travelcard before then, you can receive a temporary SwissPass from us.

question: For what age and how long is the Children’s Co-Travelcard valid?
answer: The Children’s Co-Travelcard is valid for children aged 6 or over and under 16 for one year or until the day before their 16th birthday (at the latest).

question: What about grandma and grandpa? Does a child then need two Children’s Co-Travelcards?
answer: If a child travels together with their grandma or together with their grandpa, a separate Children’s Co-Travelcard is required for both their grandma and for their grandpa. If a child travels with their grandma and their grandpa also comes along, then only one Children’s Co-Travelcard is required (for grandma and child). The Children’s Co-Travelcard is always valid for the child and the stated companion.                                             More on the Children’s Co-Travelcard

question: Is the Children’s Co-Travelcard of the child linked to the SwissPass of their companion?
answer: Yes. The Children’s Co-Travelcard is linked to the companion’s SwissPass. The child remains the holder of the travelcard.

question: Can a child travel with the Children’s Co-Travelcard without being accompanied by an adult?
answer: No. The Children’s Co-Travelcard is only valid for travel with a companion (aged 16 or over). The companion must have a valid ticket for 1st or 2nd class.

question: Can I buy a second SwissPass card?
answer: No. Each person can hold only one active SwissPass card. If for example the child loses their SwissPass card and a replacement SwissPass card was therefore issued, the first card is blocked and can no longer be used. That is how we prevent misuse of the first card.

question: How can I renew the Children’s Co-Travelcard on the SwissPass card?
answer: Online renewal. As long as no changes are needed, you can renew the Children’s Co-Travelcard conveniently online. (You do not need a login).. Here’s how it works.  The registered companion receives a reminder by e-mail. Click on the link in the e-mail and renew the Children’s Co-Travelcard.  Would you rather receive an SMS text than an e-mail? On swisspass.ch, you can change the contact channels under ‘Contact channel’ as the companion.                                             Go to ‘Contact channel’ settings on swisspass.ch                         Link opens in new window.                                       Renewal at the ticket machine. Alternatively, you can also renew the Children’s Co-Travelcard at ticket machines. Use the scan function to do so.

question: Will I be informed if the Children’s Co-Travelcard is about to expire?
answer: We will inform the registered companion as follows:  6 weeks before the last day of validity of the travelcard, we send information telling you that it will soon expire – by SMS text or e-mail depending on your preference. The message will contain a link which you can click on to renew your travelcard conveniently. Shortly before / after the first and last day of validity, we will send another reminder – by SMS text or e-mail depending on your preference.

question: What happens during ticket inspection?
answer: During the ticket inspection, either the child presents their own SwissPass card or you as the companion show your SwissPass card. The Children’s Co-Travelcard can be checked on both the child’s and the companion’s SwissPass.  The passenger attendant will check whether the right person is travelling with the child. The first names, surnames and photographs of the permitted companions or children are shown to the train crew via the ticket checking device. This information is then checked against the official ID or SwissPass presented. You must also show your own ticket or travelcard (separate ticket, GA Travelcard etc.) at the same time. If the child and/or the companion use SwissPass Mobile (e.g. in the SBB Mobile app), the Children’s Co-Travelcard can also be checked on a smartphone.                                              Go to SwissPass Mobile

question: Can I show the Children’s Co-Travelcard on my smartphone via the SBB Mobile app?
answer: Yes. To display the child’s SwissPass Card via the SwissPass Mobile function (e.g. in the SBB Mobile app), the child needs their own SwissPass login. You will find instructions on how to do this on the general questions on logins page.  To ensure ticket inspection is possible via the app, the child and/or the companion must have a SwissPass login and have linked it to the app. You will find instructions on how to do this on the general questions on logins page.  Go to the SwissPass login More info about SwissPass Mobile

question: Can I exchange the Children’s Co-Travelcard or have it refunded?
answer: No, exchanges and refunds are not possible for the Children’s Co-Travelcard.

question: What do I do if I don’t want the SwissPass card for my child?
answer: The Children’s Co-Travelcard is now only available on the SwissPass. The standard range is available if you travel with children without the Children’s Co-Travelcard – for example, the Day Pass Children for CHF 19 (2nd class) or CHF 33 (1st class). The Day Pass Children is valid across the GA Travelcard area of validity.                                             Go to the Day Pass Children area of validity

question: Where can I buy the Children’s Co-Travelcard?
answer: Initial purchase on the SwissPass card. You can buy the Children’s Co-Travelcard on the SwissPass at any staffed public transport point of sale. Read the questions in the Photo and Documents sections.

question: What can I do if I have lost the Junior Travelcard or forgotten to bring it with me?
answer: Junior Travel Card on the SwissPass.  Tip: The Children’s Co-Travelcard can also be checked via the SwissPass or SwissPass Mobile of the companion.  If your SwissPass card is lost or stolen, you can order a new one. This costs CHF 30.                                               Order a replacement SwissPass card

question: Will the child receive their own SwissPass card?
answer: Yes. Every child who holds a public transport travelcard (e.g. Junior Travelcard, Children’s Co-Travelcard, Regional Travelcard) on the SwissPass has their own SwissPass card. All public transport travelcards are then stored on this card.

question: How many children with a Co-Travelcard can a companion take with them?
answer: A companion can take a maximum of four children with them. Each child must have a valid Children’s Co-Travelcard.  If you are travelling with more than four children (for example, on a school trip, for a child’s birthday, as part of a club, in a group, as a company or institution etc.), all children aged 6 or over must hold their own ticket. For groups (of children) of 10 or more passengers, you can purchase group tickets. Splitting up the group is not permitted, for example, travelling as several companions with four children each with a Children’s Co-Travelcard.  More about group tickets  Help with group tickets

question: The validity of the Children’s Co-Travelcard is no longer printed directly on the card. Where can I check it?
answer: On swisspass.ch, you can see the validity of the travelcards at any time – both in the child’s account and in the account of the accompanying person. You can also scan your child’s SwissPass at a ticket machine using the scan function to check its validity.

question: Who is the travelcard holder for the Children’s Co-Travelcard?
answer: The holder of the travelcard is always the child.

question: What documents do I need to purchase the Children’s Co-Travelcard for the first time on the SwissPass?
answer: For an initial purchase of a Children’s Co-Travelcard, please bring official ID for both the child and the companion.

question: What is the Children’s Co-Travelcard?
answer: The Children’s Co-Travelcard allows children aged at least 6 and under 16 to travel for free for a whole year throughout Switzerland when accompanied by a person aged 16 or over. The companion must hold a valid ticket (e.g. a ticket, a GA Travelcard, a Point-to-Point Travelcard). The Children’s Co-Travelcard is issued on the SwissPass. A companion can take a maximum of four children with them. Each child must have their own Children’s Co-Travelcard.

question: Why does the child receive their own SwissPass card?
answer: The Children’s Co-Travelcard is a personal travelcard and is therefore only stored on the child’s own personal SwissPass. Other travelcards: as the child grows older, it is increasingly likely that they will purchase other personal travelcards for travelling independently. A large number of children under 16 already have their own SwissPass card. Additional advantages: the child will also be able to enjoy other advantages. For example, partner services such as ski passes or admission tickets that are deposited on the SwissPass card. Sustainability: the card can be used for five years and can hold numerous different offers. This means that a new plastic card doesn’t need to be produced every year.

question: How much does the Children’s Co-Travelcard cost?
answer: The Children’s Co-Travelcard is issued per child and companion and costs CHF 30.

question: What do I have to take into account regarding the photo?
answer: Requirements. For the travelcard on the SwissPass, you need to provide a recent passport photo of the child which fulfils the following criteria:  Taken from the front. Eyes open and not covered. Plain background. Even lighting (no shadows). Clear with high contrast. Black and white or colour. Approx. size 35mm × 45mm. Analogue passport photo: only original prints, no scans or photos printed out on paper. Digital passport photo: unedited, min. image size 200 × 250 pixels; in .JPG or .JPEG format with a maximum size of 4MB.  Purchasing the travelcard for the first time at a staffed point of sale. Please bring a recent analogue or digital passport photo to the counter. Online renewal of a Children’s Co-Travelcard. If the child already holds a SwissPass, the same photo will be used. Children and young people aged at least 6 and under 25 only need a new photo if the current photo was taken more than five years ago.

question: What payment methods can I use to pay for a Children’s Co-Travelcard?
answer: Initial purchase on the SwissPass card. For an initial purchase, the following payment methods are available at staffed points of sale: cash, vouchers, Reka Check, Reka Rail, Twint, debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne). Renew (the Children’s Co-Travelcard is already on the SwissPass). If you renew the Children’s Co-Travelcard online, you can pay with a credit card, PostFinance card, Reka card, by monthly invoicing or with Twint. If you renew the Children’s Co-Travelcard at a staffed point of sale, the following payment methods are available: cash, vouchers, Reka Check, Reka Rail, Twint, debit or credit card (PostFinance Card, Mastercard, Visa, Reka Card, American Express, Diners, JCB or myOne).

question: Does my child need their own login for swisspass.ch?
answer: No. If you always just show the SwissPass card, a separate login is not needed. The child only needs a login if they want to show the Children’s Co-Travelcard in an app (e.g. SBB Mobile).

question: Where is the Day Pass Children valid?
answer: The Day Pass Children is valid within the GA Travelcard area of validity.                                              Go to the Day Pass Children area of validity

question: What is the Children’s Co-Travelcard?
answer: The Children’s Co-Travelcard allows children aged at least 6 and under 16 to travel for free for a whole year throughout Switzerland when accompanied by a person aged 16 or over. The companion must hold a valid ticket (e.g. a ticket, a GA Travelcard, a Point-to-Point Travelcard). The companion does not need a SwissPass themselves to buy a Children’s Co-Travelcard for the child. The Children’s Co-Travelcard is issued on the SwissPass. A companion can take a maximum of four children with them. Each child must have their own Children’s Co-Travelcard. More on the Children’s Co-Travelcard  Questions and answers about the Children’s Co-Travelcard

question: Which documents do I need to purchase a Day Pass Children?
answer: None. The Day Pass for Children is available for all children aged at least 6 and under 16. For ticket inspection, the child must always have their personal ID or a SwissPass with them.

question: What is the difference between a Day Pass Children and the Children’s Co-Travelcard or the Junior Travelcard?
answer: The Day Pass Children is a normal Day Pass, but just at a greatly reduced price. With the Day Pass Children, a child aged under 16 can travel alone throughout Switzerland for an entire day. An adult must always travel with a child using a Children’s Co-Travelcard. With the Junior Travelcard, a parent must always accompany the child.                                              More about the Day Pass Children

question: What is the difference between the Junior Travelcard and the Children’s Co-Travelcard?
answer: With the Children’s Co-Travelcard, a child can travel together with a selected adult (aged 16 or over) for a whole year throughout Switzerland. With the Junior Travelcard, the child can travel together with a parent for a whole year throughout Switzerland.  Important: in all cases, each child requires their own Junior Travelcard or Children’s Co-Travelcard. In addition, the adult companion or the parent requires a valid ticket.

question: What is the Junior Travelcard?
answer: The Junior Travelcard allows children aged at least 6 and under 16 to travel for free for a whole year throughout Switzerland with a parent. Parents do not need a SwissPass themselves to buy a Junior Travelcard for their child. The accompanying parent must hold a valid ticket for 2nd or 1st class (e.g. a ticket, GA Travelcard, Point-to-Point Travelcard); the child can travel in either class for free. The Junior Travelcard is free from the third child. The Junior Travelcard is issued on the SwissPass. More about the Junior Travelcard  Questions and answers about the Junior Travelcard

question: How much does the Day Pass Children cost?
answer: The Day Pass Children costs CHF 19 per day for 2nd class and CHF 33 for 1st class.

question: What is a GA Travelcard for Children?
answer: With a GA Travelcard for Children, children aged 6 or over and under 16 can travel alone and without restriction on public transport in Switzerland. The GA Travelcard for Children is a full GA Travelcard but at a reduced price.  It is ideal for children who commute to school or regularly travel on public transport, for example. Tip: if a parent holds a GA Travelcard, we recommend you purchase a GA Travelcard Familia for Children. More about the GA Travelcard for Children  More about the GA Travelcard Familia for Children  Help with the GA Travelcard

question: Where can I buy the Day Pass Children?
answer: The Day Pass Children is available online on SBB.ch, in the SBB Mobile app, at ticket machines and at public transport points of sale.                                              Purchase a Day Pass Children online                                                                Here’s how to purchase in the SBB Mobile app.  Open the SBB Mobile app.  Switch to ‘Shop & Services’ in the navigation bar at the bottom of the screen and tap on ‘Day Pass Children’. Tap on ‘Edit passenger’ (pencil icon) and enter the child’s first name, surname and date of birth. Then tap on ‘Save’. Under ‘Who is travelling?’, tick the box next to the child who is travelling and untick your own name (if the child is travelling alone). Tap on ‘Accept’.  The Day Pass for Children now appears in the list of options. Follow the purchasing process.  If the child is travelling without a smartphone: please print out the Day Pass Children via the link in the confirmation e-mail and give it to the child to present during the ticket inspection.

question: Where and how can I purchase a GA Travelcard for Children?
answer: More about options for purchasing Help with the GA Travelcard

question: Is the GA Travelcard for Children available on the SwissPass?
answer: Yes, the GA Travelcard for Children is available on the SwissPass.

question: How much does a GA Travelcard for Children cost?
answer: The GA Travelcard for Children costs CHF 1,645 per year for 2nd class and CHF 2,760 per year for 1st class.

question: What is a GA Travelcard Familia for Children?
answer: If at least one parent in the same household has a basic GA Travelcard (possible basic GA Travelcards are the GA Travelcards for Adults, GA Travelcard for Youth, GA Travelcard for 25 Year Olds, GA Travelcard for Seniors or GA Travelcard for Disabled Persons), the GA Travelcard Familia for Children and the GA Travelcard Familia for Youth are available at a favourable price. The second parent also receives a discount (GA Travelcard Familia for Adults) if a member of the household has a Familia GA Travelcard for Children or GA Travelcard for Youth in addition to the basic GA Travelcard for the mother or father. Please note that different documents are needed in order to purchase the GA Travelcard Familia for Children, the GA Travelcard Familia for Youth and the GA Travelcard Familia for Adults. As GA Travelcards for family members are linked to a basic GA Travelcard, all GA Travelcards for one family must be on the SwissPass. More about the Familia GA Travelcard  Questions and answers about the GA Travelcard

question: My bike is less than two meters long and still doesn’t fit in the rack on the train. What can I do?
answer: In older coaches, the bicycle mounts are sometimes not set up for modern mountain bikes with 29-inch wheels and wider tires. Due to the limited space available, it is unfortunately not possible to optimise these bicycle spaces. Therefore, try turning the handlebars, removing a wheel, or maybe even let some air out of the tyre or use a bike lock to attach your bicycle to the hook. If none of this helps, contact the on-board staff so that an alternative location on the train can be found if necessary.

question: Do I need tickets for children’s bicycles?
answer: For children under 6 years old, children’s bikes are considered hand luggage and can be transported free of charge. Bambini e ragazzi in possesso di un AG Ragazzi o di un AG Famiglia Ragazzi possono portare gratuitamente la bici anche senza accompagnamento. Children with a GA Travelcard for Children or a GA Travelcard Familia for Children can take their bike with them for free even when on their own. If these conditions are not met, you will need a ticket for each children’s bike. For bicycles belonging to children aged 6 and over, you must buy a bike space reservation for trains where reservations for bicycles are compulsory.                                             Go to “Do I have to make a reservation for children’s bicycles?”

question: Which bikes and vehicles cannot be transported on public transport?
answer: Vehicles with combustion engines (e.g. mopeds), triple tandem bikes, multi-seater horizontal bicycles, personal transporter (e.g. Segways) and electric mopeds.

question: How do I buy a bike space reservation?
answer: If a bike space reservation is mandatory on your desired connection, it is best to purchase one with the SBB Mobile app. You can identify mandatory bicycle reservations by the bicycle symbol with R . With the SBB Mobile app.  Open the app. Enter the route and select your desired connection. Tap on ‘Tickets from CHF...’. Tap on ‘Edit passenger’ (pencil symbol). Tap the plus sign at the bottom next to the bicycle symbol once. Tap on ‘Accept’. Scroll down to ‘Additional offers’ then select ‘Seat reservation only’. Click on ‘Purchase ticket for CHF 2.00’.  Would you like to reserve bicycle spaces for other co-passengers? Tap the plus sign next to the bike symbol several times until you reach the desired number of bike reservations. Then complete the reservation as described above. On SBB.ch. The purchase of bike space reservations on SBB.ch is set to be introduced in April 2024. At the station.  All bike space reservations are also available at staffed public transport points of sale. Via the SBB Contact Center. Alternatively, you can reserve your bicycle space via the SBB Contact Centre on 0848 44 66 88 (CHF 0.08/min.) no later than 3 working days before the start of your journey.

question: Can I transport a bicycle trailer on the train?
answer: Yes. Please note that boarding doors and the doors between coaches on some SBB trains are only suitable for trailer widths of a maximum of 80cm and 70cm respectively. Your bicycle trailer counts as hand luggage and therefore does not require a ticket.

question: Do I need to pay for my bike?
answer: Yes. You also need a separate ticket for your bike for self-service loading of bicycles.

question: Can I take my e-moped on the train?
answer: No. You are not allowed to transport e-mopeds on the train. By e-mopeds, we mean any motorcycle-like vehicle which runs on electricity alone, regardless of its power.

question: What does transport or carriage of bikes mean?
answer: Self-service loading of bicycles means taking one bicycle or e-bike per person with you on the train. You can do this on most SBB trains and most trains of other transport companies, as well as with some bus companies (e.g. PostBuses). You place or hang the bicycle or e-bike in the designated area in the vehicle yourself.                                             All information about self-service loading of bicycles

question: I have an annual bike pass. Do I also need a reservation?
answer: Yes, even with an annual bike pass, you still need a reservation for trains where reservations are required.

question: Which bikes can I load myself?
answer: We distinguish between ordinary bicycles and special bicycles. Ordinary bicycles. The total length of ordinary bicycles must not exceed two metres. For self-service loading of bicycles, it does not matter whether the bicycle is electrically assisted or not.  Mountain bikes. Racing bikes. Gravel bikes. Everyday bikes etc.  Special bicycles. All bicycles which are longer than two meters, usually tandems, recumbent bicycles and cargo bicycles. Bikes allowed on InterCity (IC), InterRegio (IR), EuroCity (EC), InterCityExpress (ICE) and Railjet (RJX) trains within Switzerland.  Ordinary bicycles that are no more than two meters long. Bikes allowed on RegioExpress (RE), S-Bahn (S) and Regio (R) train categories.   In these train categories you can transport ordinary bicycles and special bicycles. Particularly in the case of special bikes, please note that escape routes, entrances and exits must always be kept clear. If you are taking special bikes along with you, you are advised to avoid peak travel times.                                              More about bikes that are allowed

question: Can I choose the storage space when making a reservation?
answer: The reservation system allocates spaces automatically. Unfortunately, it is not possible to select a specific coach.

question: What general rules apply to the self-service loading of bicycles on trains?
answer: When taking a bike on public transport, it is a requirement that you are able to load and unload it independently and store it in the holder provided. Furthermore, only one bike can be taken per person. Self-service loading of bicycles is only possible if there is sufficient space in the vehicles and it does not hinder other passengers. On modes of transport which require reservation, bicycle transport is only guaranteed if you have bought a bike space reservation in advance (check the online timetable). Escape routes, entrances and exits and access points to the engine driver’s cabin must always be kept clear. Bicycles that are very dirty may be excluded from carriage.

question: Do I need a reservation for my scooter?
answer: You do not need a reservation for your (e-)scooter, even on trains which require reservations. Exception: your (e-)scooter is too big to be stowed in a luggage stowage/niche or under or between the seats.

question: I have made a reservation for my bicycle, but I have only received a coach number, and no bike space number. Why is this?
answer: If your reservation only provides a coach number, you can store your bicycle in the train’s luggage compartment. SBB staff will assist you with loading and unloading.

question: When do I need a bike space reservation and for which trains?
answer: From 21 March to 31 October, you will need a bike space reservation for your bike on InterCity (IC) trains. In the timetable, trains requiring reservation are marked with the bike reservation symbol.  Every day for the IC2/21 lines through the Gotthard Base Tunnel (Basel/Zurich–Ticino). Every day for the IC5/51 lines at the southern foot of the Jura (Basel–Biel/Bienne, Rorschach/Zurich–Biel/Bienne–Lausanne/Geneva). From Friday to Sunday as well as Easter Monday, Ascension Day, Whit Monday and 1 August for all other InterCity lines.   You will also need a reservation throughout the year for the Swiss section of the route for the following trains operating internationally: EuroCity (EC), Intercity-Express (ICE), Railjet (RJX) and InterCity (IC) (Zurich–Schaffhausen). Please make sure to check whether your chosen train is subject to reservation in good time so that you can take your bike along with you. The online and mobile timetables are updated daily. Please note that you cannot cancel or rebook reservations for bicycle spaces.

question: How much does it cost to reserve a bicycle space?
answer: A bike space reservation costs CHF 2 for all trains within Switzerland that require a reservation. For connections involving changes, the reservation on the connecting train is free of charge.

question: For which trains to Ticino can I reserve a bicycle storage space and how can I do so?
