Zentralbahn AG (ZB)Link opens in new window.

question: Where can I collect the recovered item?
answer: If your item has been found, we will let you know where and when you can pick it up. Items cannot be collected on that same day. Depending on the station, you will be able to pick up the item within one to three days. This process cannot be sped up. Always make sure to note the relevant opening hours.

question: Where can I hand in items that I find?
answer: If you find an item on the train or at the station, you can hand it in at a staffed ticket counter. You can find an overview of station counter opening times on our pages dedicated to each station.                                             Go to counter opening times

question: Can I have my recovered item sent to me at my foreign address?
answer: Passports cannot be sent and will be delivered to the relevant embassy in Switzerland. The terms of the carrier (FedEx) apply in the case of deliveries to addresses outside Switzerland. Shipping costs in addition to fees are always charged in advance.

question: Can I have my recovered item sent to me by post?
answer: We can deliver mobile phones and keys to an address within Switzerland. The reclaim fee including shipping costs is always charged in advance.

question: How can I find out about the status of my loss report?
answer: You can find detailed instructions regarding the status of your loss report here:                                             Go to the loss report status guidance

question: How do I submit an express search request (subject to a fee)?
answer: You can find detailed instructions on how to submit an express search request (subject to a fee) here:                                             Go to the express search request guidance

question: Point-to-Point, Regional & Modular Travelcards
answer: Point-to-Point Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Regional Travelcard                                                                                                                                                                                     Modular Travelcard

question: GA Travelcard & Half Fare Travelcard
answer: GA Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    1-month GA Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Night GA Travelcard                                                                                                                                                                                     Half Fare Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Half Fare Travelcard PLUS

question: Other travelcards
answer: Leisure Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Companion Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Junior Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Children’s Co-Travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Travelcards for children                                                                                                                                                    Velo-Pass                                                                                                                                                                                     Dog Pass                                                                                                                                                    My travelcards                                                                                                                                                    Find the right public transport travelcard                                                                                                                                                    Day Pass for Schools                                                                                                                                                    Night GA Travelcard

question: What products are available on the SwissPass?
answer: Currently, public transport travelcards such as GA, Half Fare, Regional, Point-to-Point and Modular Travelcards, the Junior Travelcard and the Children’s Co-Travelcard as well as P+Rail Travelcards are available on the SwissPass. Moreover, various partner services can also be held on the SwissPass, such as Mobility passes, access to ski resorts, etc.

question: What happens with partner services stored on my card when I switch to the new card?
answer: Some partners such as Mobility or edrive automatically transfer your data. Please contact any partner services that don’t transfer the current services to the new card in order to clarify the next steps.

question: What partner services are available on the SwissPass?
answer: Go to the partner servicesLink opens in new window. Go to special offers from partnersLink opens in new window.

question: Do I always have to have the SwissPass card with me – even if I’ve activated SwissPass Mobile – or is ID enough?
answer: We recommend that you always take the SwissPass card with you on your journey – for example, in case you have no battery left or you have another technical problem.  The ticket-checking staff can call up your SwissPass details if you show official identification. However, this service is considered a “forgotten travelcard”, for which you pay a fee of CHF 5, as the check takes considerably longer than scanning the SwissPass card.                                             More information about SwissPass Mobile                         Link opens in new window.

question: What is new about the SwissPass card?
answer: The cards haven’t only changed visually, but also have improved security features and additional functions.  Payment function: pay for your tickets at ticket machines and at all staffed public transport points of sale by monthly invoice or prepaid credit. Door opener: The new SwissPass can be used as an access or identification medium by companies that use the security systems of the Swiss firm Legic. Secure online login: SwissPass supports the Fast Identity Online standard, or FIDO for short. This authentication standard is used globally to simplify the login process for devices and web services (e.g. Facebook, Google, Microsoft Office 365, etc.).

question: I’ve forgotten to bring my SwissPass card – what should I do now?
answer: Have you forgotten your SwissPass at home or in the office? If you have activated SwissPass Mobile, you can simply show your SwissPass in the SBB Mobile app (condition: the customer account is linked to your customer number). Alternatively, you can buy a temporary card at a public transport point of sale for a fee of CHF 5 on presentation of official ID.

question: Why do I need to send in a new photo for my SwissPass card?
answer: When a new SwissPass is issued, we check the photo that we have on file. If your photo has been stored for more than five or ten years when the card is replaced, we will require a new passport photo from you. A new passport photo is required  every five years (until the age of 25); every ten years (from the age of 25 and over).  We will contact you by e-mail or post when we require a new photo from you. You can find all the information about uploading photos on the SwissPass website.                                             Go to the photo upload on swisspass.ch                         Link opens in new window.

question: What is the SwissPass card?
answer: The SwissPass card is your key to mobility and leisure. The card is a carrier medium for travelcards such as the Half Fare Travelcard, GA Travelcard, Regional Travelcard or Leisure Travelcard and must be presented during an inspection on public transport. The SwissPass card can also be used as a ski pass at over 80 ski resorts. It opens the Mobility vehicle you have reserved and serves as an access medium when renting bicycles and e-bikes. The new SwissPass cards also enable you to make cashless payments for public transport – uncomplicated and secure.                                             More information on the SwissPass as a payment card                         Link opens in new window.

question: What is SwissPass Mobile and what do I need to be aware of?
answer: SwissPass Mobile lets you show the public transport travelcards on your SwissPass card conveniently on a digital device (e.g. smartphone or tablet). Various Swiss transport company apps already support SwissPass Mobile, including SBB Mobile and SBB Mobile Preview. To present your SwissPass digitally, you must be signed in to the app with the SwissPass login and have activated SwissPass Mobile. So when there’s a ticket check, you can keep the SwissPass card in your pocket. To use SwissPass Mobile, you need a valid SwissPass card, a linked SwissPass customer account and an app that supports SwissPass Mobile. If you don’t have a customer account yet, please register for one (one-time registration). Go to registration on swisspass.chLink opens in new window. More information about SwissPass MobileLink opens in new window.

question: How is data protection safeguarded?
answer: Protecting your privacy means a lot to us. We respect your identity and privacy and ensure that they are protected and that your personal data is processed in accordance with the applicable laws.  No personal data is stored on your SwissPass. Swiss transport companies cannot locate your SwissPass or use it to track your movements. Any data generated when your SwissPass is inspected on the train will immediately be deleted again after the inspection. Inspection data will therefore not be processed. No unauthorised persons will have access to your data. If your travelcards or partner services are paid for by another person or your company, that person or company will have access to the services they have paid for but not to any other data.

question: What information can I find in my SwissPass customer account?
answer: Manage your personal details conveniently online in your customer account – regardless of counter opening hours. Use your customer account for the following:  Change your name and address. Check the validity of your GA Travelcard or Half Fare Travelcard. Cancel travelcards online and activate a reminder to cancel your travelcard in time. Overview of pending and already paid invoices. View activated partner services (e.g. Mobility Carsharing).

question: How do I get my SwissPass card?
answer: SwissPass card with a travelcard. When you buy a public transport travelcard for the first time, you automatically receive the SwissPass card free of charge with your travelcard. You can get your travelcard online or at a staffed public transport point of sale. Your identity will be verified when you make the purchase. When purchasing at a point of sale, you must present a passport or ID card to verify your identity. Please also bring a recent passport photo along with you. When purchasing online, the identity check forms part of the purchasing process. To complete the check, you will need a passport or an ID card and a smartphone with a camera. You will also need a recent, high-quality, digital passport photo. Important: The online purchase with identity check can only be carried out for yourself. If you buy a travelcard for another person, that person needs their own customer account in which the identity check is carried out.                                             Questions on the identity check                         Link opens in new window.                                       SwissPass card without a travelcard. You can order a card free of charge in your customer account:   Login on swisspass.ch. Select “Customer data” in the top right-hand corner of the initials. Click on “Change” under “Personal details”. “Confirm identity”.  After successful verification of your identity and photo upload, the SwissPass card will be sent to you by post. You can also get the SwissPass for free without a travelcard from public transport points of sale, meaning you can then benefit from our partner services. To get a SwissPass, please take a valid official ID and a current passport photo with you.

question: Where can I find my SwissPass customer account?
answer: Go to swisspass.ch Click on Sign in and sign in with your SwissPass login. You can now view your personal data and make changes.  If you don’t yet have a SwissPass login, you need to register once before you can use these services.                                             Go to registration on swisspass.ch                         Link opens in new window.

question: Do I have to be online throughout the journey to show SwissPass Mobile?
answer: No, this is not necessary. SwissPass Mobile can also be used offline. However, you need to regularly connect to the internet (we recommend doing so at least once a week). Otherwise, SwissPass Mobile will be shown as invalid.

question: How much does the Swiss Travel Pass cost?
answer: There are different versions of the Swiss Travel Pass available. The price varies depending on which one you choose.                                             Go to offers and prices for the Swiss Travel Pass

question: Are there special discounts for children?
answer: Children aged 6 or over and under 16 can travel free of charge with the complimentary Swiss Family Card when accompanied by at least one parent. The accompanying parent must hold a valid ticket from the Swiss Travel System product range. Children under 6 years old can travel free of charge when accompanied by an individual with a valid ticket. Please note: to receive the Swiss Family Card directly, add the child as a passenger under ‘Add passengers’ when you buy your Swiss Travel Pass.

question: Is there a discount on the Swiss Travel Pass for young people?
answer: The Swiss Travel Pass Youth gives young persons under 25 a 30% discount on the Swiss Travel Pass. It offers the same validity.

question: How do I search timetables in Switzerland? Is there an app?
answer: We recommend the free SBB Mobile app for timetable enquiries and purchasing tickets (for example with the Swiss Half Fare Card). The app is available for both iOS and Android smartphones and tablets. The timetables for all public transport services are stored in the app. So it includes boats, mountain railways, urban public transport, etc. You can also use the app to purchase tickets for your journeys with the Swiss Half Fare Card. You can view the question ‘Can I buy Swiss Travel System offers online?’ to find out how.                                             Go to the SBB Mobile app

question: Can people who are resident in Switzerland also make use of these offers?
answer: No, Swiss Travel System offers are only valid for passengers who are resident outside of Switzerland or the Principality of Liechtenstein.

question: What are the advantages of the Swiss Travel Pass?
answer: In addition to unlimited travel on trains, Postbuses and boats, the Swiss Travel Pass enables visitors and tourists from abroad to benefit from additional advantages:  Unlimited travel on panorama trains (not including seat reservations and/or supplements). Unlimited use of public transport in over 90 Swiss cities. Free admission to over 500 museums thanks to the Swiss Museum Pass. Included mountain excursions: Rigi, Stanserhorn and Stoos. A discount of up to 50% on other mountain excursions. A discount of up to 30% on leisure travel offers. Offers are available at all public transport ticket counters in Switzerland.  Go to Swiss Travel Pass Go to leisure travel offers Go to the Swiss Museum PassLink opens in new window.

question: Are there special offers for train travel and other public transport journeys for visitors from abroad?
answer: Yes. With the Swiss Travel System, we provide tourists and visitors from abroad with advantageous tickets for travelling within Switzerland. The most important of these are:  the Swiss Travel Pass (a kind of GA Travelcard) for adults and for young people up to 26 years old. the Swiss Half Fare Card (a kind of Half Fare Travelcard for a one-month period). the Swiss Family Card (a kind of Junior Travelcard) for families with children aged between 6 and 16 years old. With this card, children can travel free of charge when accompanied by at least one parent. The accompanying parent must hold a valid ticket from the Swiss Travel System product range. Please note: to receive the Swiss Family Card directly, add the child as a passenger under ‘Add passengers’ when you buy your ticket.                                              Go to Swiss Travel System

question: How much does the Swiss Half Fare Card cost?
answer: Go to the Swiss Half Fare Card price

question: Can I buy Swiss Travel System offers online? Can I use my smartphone or tablet to display them?
answer: Yes, it is possible to purchase offers online at SBB.ch.  If you “purchase as a guest” without a login, make sure to print out your tickets afterwards. If you would like to store and retrieve your tickets digitally, then purchase them online with a login and download the SBB Mobile app on your smartphone/tablet to display them.   Purchasing online with a login on SBB.ch.  Set up a SwissPass login (the term ‘SwissPass’ is not related to ‘Swiss Travel Pass’ so you can ignore it).  Click on this login linkLink opens in new window.. Select ‘I do not have a public transport travelcard’ and enter all the required details to have your SwissPass login confirmed (e-mail address and password). You can now purchase your Swiss Travel Pass or Swiss Half Fare Card online on SBB.ch. Important: make sure you are logged in when you purchase with the SwissPass login.  Buy Swiss Travel Pass online  Buy Swiss Half Fare Card online Download the free SBB Mobile app on your smartphone or tablet. The app is available for both iOS and Android smartphones and tablets.  After downloading, log in to the app using your SwissPass login.  Under the ‘Tickets & SwissPass’ tile, you will see your Swiss Travel Pass or Swiss Half Fare Card.  Important: if you purchased your Swiss Travel Pass or Swiss Half Fare Card without a login or via another vendor, it cannot be displayed in the SBB Mobile app.  Tip: if you have a Swiss Half Fare Card, you can also use the SBB Mobile app to purchase tickets for your journeys within Switzerland for half price.  To make sure that you purchase the correct tickets at the correct prices, follow these steps:  Click the menu (the three horizontal bars). Select ‘Settings’ and then ‘My Travelcards’. Click on ‘Store travelcard manually’ and select ‘Half-Fare travelcard (1/2)’. Then confirm your entry by clicking on ‘Accept’. Now you will always be shown the half-price tickets that your Swiss Half Fare Card entitles you to when you search the timetable. And you can also purchase these tickets.

question: What’s the best way to plan my travel in Switzerland? Is there an app?
answer: The Swiss Travel Guide App for iOS and Android is a great tool for planning your journey through Switzerland and has lots of tips to inspire you. Whether it's a journey on the panorama train, a boat excursion or a visit to the museum – the app shows you over 500 Swiss highlights that you can call up and add to your personal travel cockpit any time, regardless of where you are, via an integrated map. This helps you get the most out of your trip, letting you enjoy all the attractions along the way.                                             Go to the Swiss Travel Guide app                         Link opens in new window.

question: Where can I purchase the Swiss Travel Pass and the Swiss Half Fare Card?
answer: You can purchase these tickets online at SBB.ch. Find out how in the next question. You can also purchase all Swiss Travel System tickets at any staffed public transport point of sale throughout Switzerland, as well as from sales partners in many countries around the world.                                             List of Swiss Travel System sales partners (PDF)                         Link opens in new window.

question: Is a free internet connection available on the trains?
answer: With the SBB FreeSurf app, SBB provides a quick and secure internet connection free of charge on all national long-distance trains. Passengers from abroad can surf the net free of charge with a Sunrise SIM card.                                              Go to SBB FreeSurf

question: I feel ill on tilting trains. Can I exclude tilting trains from my travel search?
answer: You can exclude tilting trains via the advanced search on SBB.ch. To do this, you must choose “no tilting trains”. This connection filter is not available in the SBB Mobile app.

question: What calculations are behind the online timetable display?
answer: The calculations behind it are highly complex. The following rules influence the search results:  Priority 1: the fastest connection. Priority 2: the most convenient connection (fewest changes). Priority 3: the connection with the best train categories (e.g. an IC has priority over an S-Bahn).  The search results generated by this base calculation can also be influenced by:  personalised searches, such as “carriage of bicycles”, “via field”, “barrier-free travel” etc., which can be set in the advanced search. popular alternative routes: for example, for the Bern – Brig route, both possible routes (1x via Lötschberg tunnel and 1x via the mountain route) are shown in the timetable.  All timetable queries take real time data into account. That means that alternative routes can also be offered.

question: Why is a certain connection not in the timetable?
answer: The reasons may be the following:  The train is cancelled, e.g. because of engineering works. Timetable data for international passenger services is not up to date because the timetable data abroad is often not updated as frequently as data from Switzerland.

question: How is an interchange shown?
answer: For changes, the same information is displayed in the SBB Mobile app and in the online timetable on SBB.ch, only they are displayed slightly differently. Interchange at the same stop. Given in the timetable as interchange with no time or metre distance indications. Example: From Bern, platform 4 to Bern, platform 10.  Interchange at the same location, but to a different transport service. Given in the timetable as “walk”, including time indication, but no distance indication in metres. Example: From Luzern, platform 3 to Luzern, Bahnhof, stand B. Note: If the stop carries the adjunct “station”, this refers to a bus or tram stop outside of the railway station.  Example: The stop “Luzern” = railway station. “Luzern, Bahnhof” = bus/tram stop. Travel from/to address. Given in the timetable as “walk” including time indication and distance indication in metres, since geographical coordinates are available. Transfer on foot + by bus/tram. Listed in the timetable as walk+bus or walk+tram, including time indication, but without distance indication.

question: What does an “unspecified delay” mean?
answer: On Swiss railways, “unspecified delay” means that no prediction can be made as to when a service will continue its journey or stop at or depart from a later station.   Possible reasons for an “unspecified delay”:  A train has a technical problem at the station or on the route which cannot be resolved within a fixed time frame. A problem with the infrastructure cannot be resolved within a fixed time frame, causing suspension of service on the line (e.g. broken rail, damage to the catenary). Natural disasters (e.g. landslide) causing suspension of service on the line.  There is a medical emergency.

question: What information is provided in real time?
answer: Delays. Delays affecting critical changes of train. Delays of unspecified duration. Cancellations. Alternative connections. Platform alterations. Unscheduled station stops. Unscheduled omissions of station stops.  The following are inputted manually:  Disruptions. Information. Delays. Rail replacement services. Engineering work. Any other notices.

question: I specifically want to travel by IC. How can I filter the connections shown to only show a special type of train?
answer: When you use the advanced search on SBB.ch and in SBB Mobile you have the option of choosing trains of a given category. This way you can influence the choice of connections shown. To open the advanced search in the SBB Mobile app, tap the symbol with the three circles on the three lines on the right-hand side when searching the timetable. On SBB.ch, simply click on ‘Advanced search’ to the right of ‘Search for connection’, once you have entered your departure and destination locations. Generally, when making a general search for connections (without applying filters) the most convenient and fastest connection is selected.

question: Where can I find the digital timetable?
answer: You can access the timetable directly on the SBB.ch homepage or in the ‘Plan’ tab in the SBB Mobile/SBB Preview app.                                             To the timetable

question: How is interchange time calculated?
answer: Since stations and stops differ in size, passengers need different lengths of time to get from A to B. The timetable therefore provides different interchange times for switching from one mode of transport to another for each stop. The standard time is 2 minutes. However, for larger stations, this interchange time is increased, for instance, to 7 minutes for Zürich HB. You can also customise the interchange time on SBB.ch.  Go to ‘Settings’ and click on the circle next to ‘Interchange time’. You can then extend the interchange time by 50% or 100% (twice as long).   Note: You cannot adjust the interchange time in the SBB Mobile / Preview app.

question: Why can I see the delay on the departure board at the station, but not in the SBB Mobile app or on SBB.ch?
answer: The online channels retrieve their data via a different path to the departure boards at stations. The data processing and transfer time means that data appear on online channels with a delay of 1-2 minutes.

question: How are delay minutes calculated?
answer: Under 3 minutes: no indication(?)Show note indicationException: If an alternative journey is shown, delays of one minute or more will be shown. Close note.  From 3 to 20 minutes: in minute intervals. From 21 to 90 minutes: rounded down to the nearest 5 minutes. From 91 minutes: the newly calculated departure time will be shown.  Delays of unspecified duration: the exact extent of the delay cannot be estimated currently. A more reliable forecast will be added as soon it is possible.

question: Which transport companies do I receive delay confirmations from?
answer: We offer confirmations of delays, for the following transport companies:  SBB Zentralbahn SOB Thurbo BLS TPF Region Alps  You can request a confirmation of delay online.                                             Request a confirmation of delay                                                                For all other transport companies, please contact the customer service of the individual transport company.

question: Why is the official timetable no longer available in print?
answer: Due to the sharp downturn in demand in recent years following the newly offered digital format for timetables, the official timetable is no longer printed. However, you can still find it in PDF form at fahrplanfelder.ch/en.                                             Click here for the official timetable                         Link opens in new window.

question: Where can I find relevant information in the event of disruption and restrictions on the rail network?
answer: A complete overview of the current service situation is available on the “Operations and disruptions” page.                                             Click here to view the service situation

question: How can I activate notifications concerning delays, platform changes or cancellations for a connection?
answer: If you would like to be informed about changes to your journey, such as platform changes, delays or cancellations, you can subscribe to notifications about the connection via the SBB Mobile app. Swipe your preferred connection to the right.  Alternatively, select your preferred connection, go to the detailed view and click on 'Add to My Trips'. The connections you have subscribed to will be shown in the ‘Trips and Tickets’ section. By subscribing to a journey, you will be kept informed about developments on that route in real time via push notifications. For this to work, please ensure that you have turned on notifications in the app under ‘Settings’ -> ‘Notifications’. You can turn on notifications for information relating to disruption (platform changes, cancellations, delays) and also for information relating to changing vehicles. If you no longer wish to receive information about the journeys you have subscribed to, you can turn off notifications for them at any time. To do so, please return to the ‘Trips and Tickets’ section and delete the relevant connection. You will then receive no further notifications for that connection.

question: What do the different labels and icons in the timetable mean?
answer: Fahrplanfelder.ch provides a list of all the symbols used in the timetable.                                             Click here to view the list of icons                         Link opens in new window.

question: How do I know if my connection is affected by engineering works?
answer: The timetable is updated promptly and in advance with planned changes to travel times due to engineering works. If you receive a message that says the timetable has been updated due to engineering works, you can assume that the relevant changes are visible in the timetable and the connections affected have been updated. Aside from engineering works, disruptions can also lead to unplanned changes at short notice. We therefore recommend that you always check your connection before departure in the online timetable or the SBB Mobile app.

question: My preferred connection is not shown. Why is that?
answer: Your preferred connection may not be shown for various reasons:  The interchange time falls short of the required interchange time (or that set in the advanced search). A faster, more convenient connection is available. You have restricted your selection via the advanced search.  You may be able to find your preferred connection by selecting “consider alternative stops at departure point/destination” on SBB.ch. Reason: Construction works can mean that stops are temporarily moved.

question: We are travelling as a group. What must I remember when searching for connections?
answer: When searching for connections on SBB.ch, you can choose “group travel (Switzerland only)”. This lets you filter for connections which can carry groups as a matter of course.  There are some transport services (e.g. some small buses) which are not able to transport groups. They are then not shown in the selection.                                             Reserve your group journey

question: Which stops, addresses and sights are recommended to me?
answer: The stops, addresses and sights recommended depend on the following criteria:  Number of elements in the information entered corresponding to the stop name. Example: Entry “mün mät” for “Münchenbuchsee, Mätteli”. Corresponding character length.  Example: Entry “Langen Kantonalbank” for “Langenthal, Tell/Kantonalbank”. “Langnau am Albis, Zürcher Kantonalbank” is weighted less because the text is longer. Weighting of traffic volume. If a stop is served by a higher number of journeys, this is listed first. Example: When entering “Zürich”, “Zürich HB” comes up before “Zürich Flughafen” or “Zürich Altstetten”. Sequence of locations (only in the SBB Mobile app). If stops have already been searched once before on the same smartphone, they are listed first in a separate table list as fast choices.

question: What does ‘information status of the timetable’ mean?
answer: We regularly update our timetable data so that SBB Mobile and SBB.ch always get you the best services. This takes account of timetable adjustments for building works as well as extra services put on for special events. We are also constantly expanding the scope of the real-time information that we have stored to inform you quickly and reliably in the event of disruptions or platform or formation changes, for example.

question: Where can I find timetables in PDF form?
answer: You can find pocket timetables, departure boards and network maps, as well as personal pocket timetables for any route, on the “PDF timetables” page.                                             PDF timetables                                                                All timetables in the official timetable of Switzerland are available at fahrplanfelder.ch.                                             Click here to go to the timetables                         Link opens in new window.

question: What is the difference between target data and actual data?
answer: The target data reflects the planned status of the timetable – how the timetable should look, in other words. The actual data, however, shows the current service status at any given time: i.e. the actual rail traffic situation – including any disruptions. Both types of data are combined to calculate the best service for you.

question: I am a wheelchair user. How can I find an accessible connection?
answer: The online timetable (SBB.ch) shows whether your train journey is accessible (“barrier-free”). You can filter for the following barrier-free statuses using the advanced search. Self-boarding/alighting possible. Assistance with boarding and alighting from the train crew. Assistance with boarding and alighting with prior registration with the Contact Center Handicap.  Carriage not possible. No information available. If the whole connection shows the status “independent boarding and alighting possible”, you can travel without assistance.  To use other connections, you may need help boarding or alighting. In this case, our staff can help you: reserve help via Contact Center Handicap, telephone number 0800 007 102 (toll-free in Switzerland, from 5am to 12pm). You can find more information on accessible travel in the brochure “Accessible travel. Public transport passengers with reduced mobility” or directly online.   More information on accessible travel Downloads. Accessible travel. Public transport passengers with reduced mobility (PDF, 699 KB) Download The link destination will be opened in an external application or a new window (PDF, 699 KB) Link opens in new window.This document is not barrier-free.
